text: Many people have set out to write accounts about the events that have been fulfilled among us.
speaker: Narrator

text: They used the eyewitness reports circulating among us from the early disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: Having carefully investigated everything from the beginning, I also have decided to write an accurate account for you, most honorable Theophilus,
speaker: Narrator

text: so you can be certain of the truth of everything you were taught.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Herod was king of Judea, there was a Jewish priest named Zechariah. He was a member of the priestly order of Abijah, and his wife, Elizabeth, was also from the priestly line of Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah and Elizabeth were righteous in God’s eyes, careful to obey all of the Lord’s commandments and regulations.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had no children because Elizabeth was unable to conceive, and they were both very old.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Zechariah was serving God in the Temple, for his order was on duty that week.
speaker: Narrator

text: As was the custom of the priests, he was chosen by lot to enter the sanctuary of the Lord and burn incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the incense was being burned, a great crowd stood outside, praying.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Zechariah was in the sanctuary, an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing to the right of the incense altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah was shaken and overwhelmed with fear when he saw him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel said, “Don’t be afraid, Zechariah! God has heard your prayer. Your wife, Elizabeth, will give you a son, and you are to name him John.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have great joy and gladness, and many will rejoice at his birth,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he will be great in the eyes of the Lord. He must never touch wine or other alcoholic drinks. He will be filled with the Holy Spirit, even before his birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he will turn many Israelites to the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be a man with the spirit and power of Elijah. He will prepare the people for the coming of the Lord. He will turn the hearts of the fathers to their children, and he will cause those who are rebellious to accept the wisdom of the godly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah said to the angel, “How can I be sure this will happen? I’m an old man now, and my wife is also well along in years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel said, “I am Gabriel! I stand in the very presence of God. It was he who sent me to bring you this good news!
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, since you didn’t believe what I said, you will be silent and unable to speak until the child is born. For my words will certainly be fulfilled at the proper time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the people were waiting for Zechariah to come out of the sanctuary, wondering why he was taking so long.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he finally did come out, he couldn’t speak to them. Then they realized from his gestures and his silence that he must have seen a vision in the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zechariah’s week of service in the Temple was over, he returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon afterward his wife, Elizabeth, became pregnant and went into seclusion for five months.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How kind the Lord is!” she exclaimed. “He has taken away my disgrace of having no children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a village in Galilee,
speaker: Narrator

text: to a virgin named Mary. She was engaged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gabriel appeared to her and said, “Greetings, favored woman! The Lord is with you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Confused and disturbed, Mary tried to think what the angel could mean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t be afraid, Mary,” the angel told her, “for you have found favor with God!
speaker: Jesus

text: You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you will name him Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be very great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his ancestor David.
speaker: Jesus

text: And he will reign over Israel forever; his Kingdom will never end!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Mary asked the angel, “But how can this happen? I am a virgin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God.
speaker: Jesus

text: What’s more, your relative Elizabeth has become pregnant in her old age! People used to say she was barren, but she has conceived a son and is now in her sixth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the word of God will never fail.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Mary responded, “I am the Lord’s servant. May everything you have said about me come true.” And then the angel left her.
speaker: Narrator

text: A few days later Mary hurried to the hill country of Judea, to the town
speaker: Narrator

text: where Zechariah lived. She entered the house and greeted Elizabeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the sound of Mary’s greeting, Elizabeth’s child leaped within her, and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elizabeth gave a glad cry and exclaimed to Mary, “God has blessed you above all women, and your child is blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why am I so honored, that the mother of my Lord should visit me?
speaker: Narrator

text: When I heard your greeting, the baby in my womb jumped for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are blessed because you believed that the Lord would do what he said.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mary responded,
“Oh, how my soul praises the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: How my spirit rejoices in God my Savior!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he took notice of his lowly servant girl,
    and from now on all generations will call me blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Mighty One is holy,
    and he has done great things for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shows mercy from generation to generation
    to all who fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His mighty arm has done tremendous things!
    He has scattered the proud and haughty ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has brought down princes from their thrones
    and exalted the humble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has filled the hungry with good things
    and sent the rich away with empty hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has helped his servant Israel
    and remembered to be merciful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he made this promise to our ancestors,
    to Abraham and his children forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Mary stayed with Elizabeth about three months and then went back to her own home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was time for Elizabeth’s baby to be born, she gave birth to a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had been very merciful to her, everyone rejoiced with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the baby was eight days old, they all came for the circumcision ceremony. They wanted to name him Zechariah, after his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elizabeth said, “No! His name is John!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What?” they exclaimed. “There is no one in all your family by that name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they used gestures to ask the baby’s father what he wanted to name him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He motioned for a writing tablet, and to everyone’s surprise he wrote, “His name is John.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instantly Zechariah could speak again, and he began praising God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Awe fell upon the whole neighborhood, and the news of what had happened spread throughout the Judean hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who heard about it reflected on these events and asked, “What will this child turn out to be?” For the hand of the Lord was surely upon him in a special way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his father, Zechariah, was filled with the Holy Spirit and gave this prophecy:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Praise the Lord, the God of Israel,
    because he has visited and redeemed his people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has sent us a mighty Savior
    from the royal line of his servant David,
speaker: Narrator

text:
just as he promised
    through his holy prophets long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now we will be saved from our enemies
    and from all who hate us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has been merciful to our ancestors
    by remembering his sacred covenant—
speaker: Narrator

text:
the covenant he swore with an oath
    to our ancestor Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have been rescued from our enemies
    so we can serve God without fear,
speaker: Narrator

text:
in holiness and righteousness
    for as long as we live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And you, my little son,
    will be called the prophet of the Most High,
    because you will prepare the way for the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will tell his people how to find salvation
    through forgiveness of their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because of God’s tender mercy,
    the morning light from heaven is about to break upon us,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to give light to those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death,
    and to guide us to the path of peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: John grew up and became strong in spirit. And he lived in the wilderness until he began his public ministry to Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Roman emperor, Augustus, decreed that a census should be taken throughout the Roman Empire.
speaker: Narrator

text: (This was the first census taken when Quirinius was governor of Syria.)
speaker: Narrator

text: All returned to their own ancestral towns to register for this census.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because Joseph was a descendant of King David, he had to go to Bethlehem in Judea, David’s ancient home. He traveled there from the village of Nazareth in Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took with him Mary, to whom he was engaged, who was now expecting a child.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while they were there, the time came for her baby to be born.
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave birth to her firstborn son. She wrapped him snugly in strips of cloth and laid him in a manger, because there was no lodging available for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night there were shepherds staying in the fields nearby, guarding their flocks of sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, an angel of the Lord appeared among them, and the radiance of the Lord’s glory surrounded them. They were terrified,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the angel reassured them. “Don’t be afraid!” he said. “I bring you good news that will bring great joy to all people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Savior—yes, the Messiah, the Lord—has been born today in Bethlehem, the city of David!
speaker: Narrator

text: And you will recognize him by this sign: You will find a baby wrapped snugly in strips of cloth, lying in a manger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, the angel was joined by a vast host of others—the armies of heaven—praising God and saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Glory to God in highest heaven,
    and peace on earth to those with whom God is pleased.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angels had returned to heaven, the shepherds said to each other, “Let’s go to Bethlehem! Let’s see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They hurried to the village and found Mary and Joseph. And there was the baby, lying in the manger.
speaker: Narrator

text: After seeing him, the shepherds told everyone what had happened and what the angel had said to them about this child.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who heard the shepherds’ story were astonished,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Mary kept all these things in her heart and thought about them often.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shepherds went back to their flocks, glorifying and praising God for all they had heard and seen. It was just as the angel had told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eight days later, when the baby was circumcised, he was named Jesus, the name given him by the angel even before he was conceived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it was time for their purification offering, as required by the law of Moses after the birth of a child; so his parents took him to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The law of the Lord says, “If a woman’s first child is a boy, he must be dedicated to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they offered the sacrifice required in the law of the Lord—“either a pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time there was a man in Jerusalem named Simeon. He was righteous and devout and was eagerly waiting for the Messiah to come and rescue Israel. The Holy Spirit was upon him
speaker: Narrator

text: and had revealed to him that he would not die until he had seen the Lord’s Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day the Spirit led him to the Temple. So when Mary and Joseph came to present the baby Jesus to the Lord as the law required,
speaker: Narrator

text: Simeon was there. He took the child in his arms and praised God, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sovereign Lord, now let your servant die in peace,
    as you have promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen your salvation,
speaker: Narrator

text: which you have prepared for all people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is a light to reveal God to the nations,
    and he is the glory of your people Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus’ parents were amazed at what was being said about him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Simeon blessed them, and he said to Mary, the baby’s mother, “This child is destined to cause many in Israel to fall, and many others to rise. He has been sent as a sign from God, but many will oppose him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, the deepest thoughts of many hearts will be revealed. And a sword will pierce your very soul.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Anna, a prophet, was also there in the Temple. She was the daughter of Phanuel from the tribe of Asher, and she was very old. Her husband died when they had been married only seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she lived as a widow to the age of eighty-four. She never left the Temple but stayed there day and night, worshiping God with fasting and prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: She came along just as Simeon was talking with Mary and Joseph, and she began praising God. She talked about the child to everyone who had been waiting expectantly for God to rescue Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus’ parents had fulfilled all the requirements of the law of the Lord, they returned home to Nazareth in Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the child grew up healthy and strong. He was filled with wisdom, and God’s favor was on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every year Jesus’ parents went to Jerusalem for the Passover festival.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus was twelve years old, they attended the festival as usual.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the celebration was over, they started home to Nazareth, but Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem. His parents didn’t miss him at first,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they assumed he was among the other travelers. But when he didn’t show up that evening, they started looking for him among their relatives and friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they couldn’t find him, they went back to Jerusalem to search for him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later they finally discovered him in the Temple, sitting among the religious teachers, listening to them and asking questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who heard him were amazed at his understanding and his answers.
speaker: Narrator

text: His parents didn’t know what to think. “Son,” his mother said to him, “why have you done this to us? Your father and I have been frantic, searching for you everywhere.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But why did you need to search?” he asked. “Didn’t you know that I must be in my Father’s house?”
speaker: Jesus

text: But they didn’t understand what he meant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he returned to Nazareth with them and was obedient to them. And his mother stored all these things in her heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus grew in wisdom and in stature and in favor with God and all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was now the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius, the Roman emperor. Pontius Pilate was governor over Judea; Herod Antipas was ruler over Galilee; his brother Philip was ruler over Iturea and Traconitis; Lysanias was ruler over Abilene.
speaker: Narrator

text: Annas and Caiaphas were the high priests. At this time a message from God came to John son of Zechariah, who was living in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then John went from place to place on both sides of the Jordan River, preaching that people should be baptized to show that they had repented of their sins and turned to God to be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isaiah had spoken of John when he said,
“He is a voice shouting in the wilderness,
‘Prepare the way for the Lord’s coming!
    Clear the road for him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The valleys will be filled,
    and the mountains and hills made level.
The curves will be straightened,
    and the rough places made smooth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And then all people will see
    the salvation sent from God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the crowds came to John for baptism, he said, “You brood of snakes! Who warned you to flee the coming wrath?
speaker: Narrator

text: Prove by the way you live that you have repented of your sins and turned to God. Don’t just say to each other, ‘We’re safe, for we are descendants of Abraham.’ That means nothing, for I tell you, God can create children of Abraham from these very stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even now the ax of God’s judgment is poised, ready to sever the roots of the trees. Yes, every tree that does not produce good fruit will be chopped down and thrown into the fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowds asked, “What should we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: John replied, “If you have two shirts, give one to the poor. If you have food, share it with those who are hungry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Even corrupt tax collectors came to be baptized and asked, “Teacher, what should we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Collect no more taxes than the government requires.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What should we do?” asked some soldiers.
John replied, “Don’t extort money or make false accusations. And be content with your pay.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone was expecting the Messiah to come soon, and they were eager to know whether John might be the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: John answered their questions by saying, “I baptize you with water; but someone is coming soon who is greater than I am—so much greater that I’m not even worthy to be his slave and untie the straps of his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is ready to separate the chaff from the wheat with his winnowing fork. Then he will clean up the threshing area, gathering the wheat into his barn but burning the chaff with never-ending fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: John used many such warnings as he announced the Good News to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: John also publicly criticized Herod Antipas, the ruler of Galilee, for marrying Herodias, his brother’s wife, and for many other wrongs he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Herod put John in prison, adding this sin to his many others.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when the crowds were being baptized, Jesus himself was baptized. As he was praying, the heavens opened,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Holy Spirit, in bodily form, descended on him like a dove. And a voice from heaven said, “You are my dearly loved Son, and you bring me great joy.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus was about thirty years old when he began his public ministry.
Jesus was known as the son of Joseph.
Joseph was the son of Heli.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Heli was the son of Matthat.
Matthat was the son of Levi.
Levi was the son of Melki.
Melki was the son of Jannai.
Jannai was the son of Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joseph was the son of Mattathias.
Mattathias was the son of Amos.
Amos was the son of Nahum.
Nahum was the son of Esli.
Esli was the son of Naggai.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Naggai was the son of Maath.
Maath was the son of Mattathias.
Mattathias was the son of Semein.
Semein was the son of Josech.
Josech was the son of Joda.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joda was the son of Joanan.
Joanan was the son of Rhesa.
Rhesa was the son of Zerubbabel.
Zerubbabel was the son of Shealtiel.
Shealtiel was the son of Neri.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Neri was the son of Melki.
Melki was the son of Addi.
Addi was the son of Cosam.
Cosam was the son of Elmadam.
Elmadam was the son of Er.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Er was the son of Joshua.
Joshua was the son of Eliezer.
Eliezer was the son of Jorim.
Jorim was the son of Matthat.
Matthat was the son of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Levi was the son of Simeon.
Simeon was the son of Judah.
Judah was the son of Joseph.
Joseph was the son of Jonam.
Jonam was the son of Eliakim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eliakim was the son of Melea.
Melea was the son of Menna.
Menna was the son of Mattatha.
Mattatha was the son of Nathan.
Nathan was the son of David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David was the son of Jesse.
Jesse was the son of Obed.
Obed was the son of Boaz.
Boaz was the son of Salmon.
Salmon was the son of Nahshon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nahshon was the son of Amminadab.
Amminadab was the son of Admin.
Admin was the son of Arni.
Arni was the son of Hezron.
Hezron was the son of Perez.
Perez was the son of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah was the son of Jacob.
Jacob was the son of Isaac.
Isaac was the son of Abraham.
Abraham was the son of Terah.
Terah was the son of Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nahor was the son of Serug.
Serug was the son of Reu.
Reu was the son of Peleg.
Peleg was the son of Eber.
Eber was the son of Shelah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shelah was the son of Cainan.
Cainan was the son of Arphaxad.
Arphaxad was the son of Shem.
Shem was the son of Noah.
Noah was the son of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lamech was the son of Methuselah.
Methuselah was the son of Enoch.
Enoch was the son of Jared.
Jared was the son of Mahalalel.
Mahalalel was the son of Kenan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kenan was the son of Enosh.
Enosh was the son of Seth.
Seth was the son of Adam.
Adam was the son of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan River. He was led by the Spirit in the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text: where he was tempted by the devil for forty days. Jesus ate nothing all that time and became very hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the devil said to him, “If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become a loaf of bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus told him, “No! The Scriptures say, ‘People do not live by bread alone.’”
speaker: Jesus

text: Then the devil took him up and revealed to him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will give you the glory of these kingdoms and authority over them,” the devil said, “because they are mine to give to anyone I please.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give it all to you if you will worship me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus replied, “The Scriptures say,
‘You must worship the Lord your God
    and serve only him.’”
speaker: Jesus

text: Then the devil took him to Jerusalem, to the highest point of the Temple, and said, “If you are the Son of God, jump off!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Scriptures say,
‘He will order his angels to protect and guard you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they will hold you up with their hands
    so you won’t even hurt your foot on a stone.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus responded, “The Scriptures also say, ‘You must not test the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Jesus

text: When the devil had finished tempting Jesus, he left him until the next opportunity came.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus returned to Galilee, filled with the Holy Spirit’s power. Reports about him spread quickly through the whole region.
speaker: Narrator

text: He taught regularly in their synagogues and was praised by everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came to the village of Nazareth, his boyhood home, he went as usual to the synagogue on the Sabbath and stood up to read the Scriptures.
speaker: Narrator

text: The scroll of Isaiah the prophet was handed to him. He unrolled the scroll and found the place where this was written:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Spirit of the Lord is upon me,
    for he has anointed me to bring Good News to the poor.
He has sent me to proclaim that captives will be released,
    that the blind will see,
that the oppressed will be set free,
speaker: Jesus

text: and that the time of the Lord’s favor has come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He rolled up the scroll, handed it back to the attendant, and sat down. All eyes in the synagogue looked at him intently.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he began to speak to them. “The Scripture you’ve just heard has been fulfilled this very day!”
speaker: Jesus

text: Everyone spoke well of him and was amazed by the gracious words that came from his lips. “How can this be?” they asked. “Isn’t this Joseph’s son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “You will undoubtedly quote me this proverb: ‘Physician, heal yourself’—meaning, ‘Do miracles here in your hometown like those you did in Capernaum.’
speaker: Jesus

text: But I tell you the truth, no prophet is accepted in his own hometown.
speaker: Jesus

text: “Certainly there were many needy widows in Israel in Elijah’s time, when the heavens were closed for three and a half years, and a severe famine devastated the land.
speaker: Jesus

text: Yet Elijah was not sent to any of them. He was sent instead to a foreigner—a widow of Zarephath in the land of Sidon.
speaker: Jesus

text: And many in Israel had leprosy in the time of the prophet Elisha, but the only one healed was Naaman, a Syrian.”
speaker: Jesus

text: When they heard this, the people in the synagogue were furious.
speaker: Jesus

text: Jumping up, they mobbed him and forced him to the edge of the hill on which the town was built. They intended to push him over the cliff,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he passed right through the crowd and went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went to Capernaum, a town in Galilee, and taught there in the synagogue every Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There, too, the people were amazed at his teaching, for he spoke with authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when he was in the synagogue, a man possessed by a demon—an evil spirit—cried out, shouting,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go away! Why are you interfering with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!”
speaker: Jesus

text: But Jesus reprimanded him. “Be quiet! Come out of the man,” he ordered. At that, the demon threw the man to the floor as the crowd watched; then it came out of him without hurting him further.
speaker: Jesus

text: Amazed, the people exclaimed, “What authority and power this man’s words possess! Even evil spirits obey him, and they flee at his command!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The news about Jesus spread through every village in the entire region.
speaker: Narrator

text: After leaving the synagogue that day, Jesus went to Simon’s home, where he found Simon’s mother-in-law very sick with a high fever. “Please heal her,” everyone begged.
speaker: Narrator

text: Standing at her bedside, he rebuked the fever, and it left her. And she got up at once and prepared a meal for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sun went down that evening, people throughout the village brought sick family members to Jesus. No matter what their diseases were, the touch of his hand healed every one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many were possessed by demons; and the demons came out at his command, shouting, “You are the Son of God!” But because they knew he was the Messiah, he rebuked them and refused to let them speak.
speaker: Jesus

text: Early the next morning Jesus went out to an isolated place. The crowds searched everywhere for him, and when they finally found him, they begged him not to leave them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he replied, “I must preach the Good News of the Kingdom of God in other towns, too, because that is why I was sent.”
speaker: Jesus

text: So he continued to travel around, preaching in synagogues throughout Judea.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as Jesus was preaching on the shore of the Sea of Galilee, great crowds pressed in on him to listen to the word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He noticed two empty boats at the water’s edge, for the fishermen had left them and were washing their nets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stepping into one of the boats, Jesus asked Simon, its owner, to push it out into the water. So he sat in the boat and taught the crowds from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, “Now go out where it is deeper, and let down your nets to catch some fish.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Master,” Simon replied, “we worked hard all last night and didn’t catch a thing. But if you say so, I’ll let the nets down again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And this time their nets were so full of fish they began to tear!
speaker: Narrator

text: A shout for help brought their partners in the other boat, and soon both boats were filled with fish and on the verge of sinking.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Simon Peter realized what had happened, he fell to his knees before Jesus and said, “Oh, Lord, please leave me—I’m such a sinful man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For he was awestruck by the number of fish they had caught, as were the others with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His partners, James and John, the sons of Zebedee, were also amazed.
Jesus replied to Simon, “Don’t be afraid! From now on you’ll be fishing for people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And as soon as they landed, they left everything and followed Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: In one of the villages, Jesus met a man with an advanced case of leprosy. When the man saw Jesus, he bowed with his face to the ground, begging to be healed. “Lord,” he said, “if you are willing, you can heal me and make me clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus reached out and touched him. “I am willing,” he said. “Be healed!” And instantly the leprosy disappeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus instructed him not to tell anyone what had happened. He said, “Go to the priest and let him examine you. Take along the offering required in the law of Moses for those who have been healed of leprosy. This will be a public testimony that you have been cleansed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But despite Jesus’ instructions, the report of his power spread even faster, and vast crowds came to hear him preach and to be healed of their diseases.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus often withdrew to the wilderness for prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day while Jesus was teaching, some Pharisees and teachers of religious law were sitting nearby. (It seemed that these men showed up from every village in all Galilee and Judea, as well as from Jerusalem.) And the Lord’s healing power was strongly with Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men came carrying a paralyzed man on a sleeping mat. They tried to take him inside to Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: but they couldn’t reach him because of the crowd. So they went up to the roof and took off some tiles. Then they lowered the sick man on his mat down into the crowd, right in front of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the man, “Young man, your sins are forgiven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisees and teachers of religious law said to themselves, “Who does he think he is? That’s blasphemy! Only God can forgive sins!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus knew what they were thinking, so he asked them, “Why do you question this in your hearts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it easier to say ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or ‘Stand up and walk’?
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will prove to you that the Son of Man has the authority on earth to forgive sins.” Then Jesus turned to the paralyzed man and said, “Stand up, pick up your mat, and go home!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And immediately, as everyone watched, the man jumped up, picked up his mat, and went home praising God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone was gripped with great wonder and awe, and they praised God, exclaiming, “We have seen amazing things today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, as Jesus left the town, he saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at his tax collector’s booth. “Follow me and be my disciple,” Jesus said to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Levi got up, left everything, and followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Levi held a banquet in his home with Jesus as the guest of honor. Many of Levi’s fellow tax collectors and other guests also ate with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisees and their teachers of religious law complained bitterly to Jesus’ disciples, “Why do you eat and drink with such scum?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, “Healthy people don’t need a doctor—sick people do.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have come to call not those who think they are righteous, but those who know they are sinners and need to repent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day some people said to Jesus, “John the Baptist’s disciples fast and pray regularly, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees. Why are your disciples always eating and drinking?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus responded, “Do wedding guests fast while celebrating with the groom? Of course not.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someday the groom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus gave them this illustration: “No one tears a piece of cloth from a new garment and uses it to patch an old garment. For then the new garment would be ruined, and the new patch wouldn’t even match the old garment.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And no one puts new wine into old wineskins. For the new wine would burst the wineskins, spilling the wine and ruining the skins.
speaker: Narrator

text: New wine must be stored in new wineskins.
speaker: Narrator

text: But no one who drinks the old wine seems to want the new wine. ‘The old is just fine,’ they say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One Sabbath day as Jesus was walking through some grainfields, his disciples broke off heads of grain, rubbed off the husks in their hands, and ate the grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some Pharisees said, “Why are you breaking the law by harvesting grain on the Sabbath?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “Haven’t you read in the Scriptures what David did when he and his companions were hungry?
speaker: Narrator

text: He went into the house of God and broke the law by eating the sacred loaves of bread that only the priests can eat. He also gave some to his companions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jesus added, “The Son of Man is Lord, even over the Sabbath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On another Sabbath day, a man with a deformed right hand was in the synagogue while Jesus was teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: The teachers of religious law and the Pharisees watched Jesus closely. If he healed the man’s hand, they planned to accuse him of working on the Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus knew their thoughts. He said to the man with the deformed hand, “Come and stand in front of everyone.” So the man came forward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to his critics, “I have a question for you. Does the law permit good deeds on the Sabbath, or is it a day for doing evil? Is this a day to save life or to destroy it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked around at them one by one and then said to the man, “Hold out your hand.” So the man held out his hand, and it was restored!
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, the enemies of Jesus were wild with rage and began to discuss what to do with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day soon afterward Jesus went up on a mountain to pray, and he prayed to God all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: At daybreak he called together all of his disciples and chose twelve of them to be apostles. Here are their names:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Simon (whom he named Peter),
Andrew (Peter’s brother),
James,
John,
Philip,
Bartholomew,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Matthew,
Thomas,
James (son of Alphaeus),
Simon (who was called the zealot),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judas (son of James),
Judas Iscariot (who later betrayed him).
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came down from the mountain, the disciples stood with Jesus on a large, level area, surrounded by many of his followers and by the crowds. There were people from all over Judea and from Jerusalem and from as far north as the seacoasts of Tyre and Sidon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had come to hear him and to be healed of their diseases; and those troubled by evil spirits were healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone tried to touch him, because healing power went out from him, and he healed everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jesus turned to his disciples and said,
“God blesses you who are poor,
    for the Kingdom of God is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God blesses you who are hungry now,
    for you will be satisfied.
God blesses you who weep now,
    for in due time you will laugh.
speaker: Narrator

text: What blessings await you when people hate you and exclude you and mock you and curse you as evil because you follow the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: When that happens, be happy! Yes, leap for joy! For a great reward awaits you in heaven. And remember, their ancestors treated the ancient prophets that same way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What sorrow awaits you who are rich,
    for you have your only happiness now.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What sorrow awaits you who are fat and prosperous now,
    for a time of awful hunger awaits you.
What sorrow awaits you who laugh now,
    for your laughing will turn to mourning and sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What sorrow awaits you who are praised by the crowds,
    for their ancestors also praised false prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But to you who are willing to listen, I say, love your enemies! Do good to those who hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who hurt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone slaps you on one cheek, offer the other cheek also. If someone demands your coat, offer your shirt also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give to anyone who asks; and when things are taken away from you, don’t try to get them back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do to others as you would like them to do to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you love only those who love you, why should you get credit for that? Even sinners love those who love them!
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you do good only to those who do good to you, why should you get credit? Even sinners do that much!
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you lend money only to those who can repay you, why should you get credit? Even sinners will lend to other sinners for a full return.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Love your enemies! Do good to them. Lend to them without expecting to be repaid. Then your reward from heaven will be very great, and you will truly be acting as children of the Most High, for he is kind to those who are unthankful and wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be compassionate, just as your Father is compassionate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not judge others, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn others, or it will all come back against you. Forgive others, and you will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give, and you will receive. Your gift will return to you in full—pressed down, shaken together to make room for more, running over, and poured into your lap. The amount you give will determine the amount you get back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus gave the following illustration: “Can one blind person lead another? Won’t they both fall into a ditch?
speaker: Narrator

text: Students are not greater than their teacher. But the student who is fully trained will become like the teacher.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And why worry about a speck in your friend’s eye when you have a log in your own?
speaker: Narrator

text: How can you think of saying, ‘Friend, let me help you get rid of that speck in your eye,’ when you can’t see past the log in your own eye? Hypocrite! First get rid of the log in your own eye; then you will see well enough to deal with the speck in your friend’s eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A good tree can’t produce bad fruit, and a bad tree can’t produce good fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: A tree is identified by its fruit. Figs are never gathered from thornbushes, and grapes are not picked from bramble bushes.
speaker: Narrator

text: A good person produces good things from the treasury of a good heart, and an evil person produces evil things from the treasury of an evil heart. What you say flows from what is in your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So why do you keep calling me ‘Lord, Lord!’ when you don’t do what I say?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will show you what it’s like when someone comes to me, listens to my teaching, and then follows it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is like a person building a house who digs deep and lays the foundation on solid rock. When the floodwaters rise and break against that house, it stands firm because it is well built.
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone who hears and doesn’t obey is like a person who builds a house right on the ground, without a foundation. When the floods sweep down against that house, it will collapse into a heap of ruins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had finished saying all this to the people, he returned to Capernaum.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the highly valued slave of a Roman officer was sick and near death.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the officer heard about Jesus, he sent some respected Jewish elders to ask him to come and heal his slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they earnestly begged Jesus to help the man. “If anyone deserves your help, he does,” they said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “for he loves the Jewish people and even built a synagogue for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jesus went with them. But just before they arrived at the house, the officer sent some friends to say, “Lord, don’t trouble yourself by coming to my home, for I am not worthy of such an honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not even worthy to come and meet you. Just say the word from where you are, and my servant will be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know this because I am under the authority of my superior officers, and I have authority over my soldiers. I only need to say, ‘Go,’ and they go, or ‘Come,’ and they come. And if I say to my slaves, ‘Do this,’ they do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus heard this, he was amazed. Turning to the crowd that was following him, he said, “I tell you, I haven’t seen faith like this in all Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the officer’s friends returned to his house, they found the slave completely healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon afterward Jesus went with his disciples to the village of Nain, and a large crowd followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A funeral procession was coming out as he approached the village gate. The young man who had died was a widow’s only son, and a large crowd from the village was with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw her, his heart overflowed with compassion. “Don’t cry!” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he walked over to the coffin and touched it, and the bearers stopped. “Young man,” he said, “I tell you, get up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the dead boy sat up and began to talk! And Jesus gave him back to his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Great fear swept the crowd, and they praised God, saying, “A mighty prophet has risen among us,” and “God has visited his people today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the news about Jesus spread throughout Judea and the surrounding countryside.
speaker: Narrator

text: The disciples of John the Baptist told John about everything Jesus was doing. So John called for two of his disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he sent them to the Lord to ask him, “Are you the Messiah we’ve been expecting, or should we keep looking for someone else?”
speaker: Narrator

text: John’s two disciples found Jesus and said to him, “John the Baptist sent us to ask, ‘Are you the Messiah we’ve been expecting, or should we keep looking for someone else?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that very time, Jesus cured many people of their diseases, illnesses, and evil spirits, and he restored sight to many who were blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told John’s disciples, “Go back to John and tell him what you have seen and heard—the blind see, the lame walk, those with leprosy are cured, the deaf hear, the dead are raised to life, and the Good News is being preached to the poor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he added, “God blesses those who do not fall away because of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After John’s disciples left, Jesus began talking about him to the crowds. “What kind of man did you go into the wilderness to see? Was he a weak reed, swayed by every breath of wind?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or were you expecting to see a man dressed in expensive clothes? No, people who wear beautiful clothes and live in luxury are found in palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Were you looking for a prophet? Yes, and he is more than a prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
John is the man to whom the Scriptures refer when they say,
‘Look, I am sending my messenger ahead of you,
    and he will prepare your way before you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, of all who have ever lived, none is greater than John. Yet even the least person in the Kingdom of God is greater than he is!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, all the people—even the tax collectors—agreed that God’s way was right, for they had been baptized by John.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisees and experts in religious law rejected God’s plan for them, for they had refused John’s baptism.
speaker: Narrator

text: “To what can I compare the people of this generation?” Jesus asked. “How can I describe them?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are like children playing a game in the public square. They complain to their friends,
‘We played wedding songs,
    and you didn’t dance,
so we played funeral songs,
    and you didn’t weep.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For John the Baptist didn’t spend his time eating bread or drinking wine, and you say, ‘He’s possessed by a demon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Son of Man, on the other hand, feasts and drinks, and you say, ‘He’s a glutton and a drunkard, and a friend of tax collectors and other sinners!’
speaker: Narrator

text: But wisdom is shown to be right by the lives of those who follow it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the Pharisees asked Jesus to have dinner with him, so Jesus went to his home and sat down to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a certain immoral woman from that city heard he was eating there, she brought a beautiful alabaster jar filled with expensive perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she knelt behind him at his feet, weeping. Her tears fell on his feet, and she wiped them off with her hair. Then she kept kissing his feet and putting perfume on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, “If this man were a prophet, he would know what kind of woman is touching him. She’s a sinner!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jesus answered his thoughts. “Simon,” he said to the Pharisee, “I have something to say to you.”
“Go ahead, Teacher,” Simon replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told him this story: “A man loaned money to two people—500 pieces of silver to one and 50 pieces to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: But neither of them could repay him, so he kindly forgave them both, canceling their debts. Who do you suppose loved him more after that?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Simon answered, “I suppose the one for whom he canceled the larger debt.”
“That’s right,” Jesus said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned to the woman and said to Simon, “Look at this woman kneeling here. When I entered your home, you didn’t offer me water to wash the dust from my feet, but she has washed them with her tears and wiped them with her hair.
speaker: Narrator

text: You didn’t greet me with a kiss, but from the time I first came in, she has not stopped kissing my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: You neglected the courtesy of olive oil to anoint my head, but she has anointed my feet with rare perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell you, her sins—and they are many—have been forgiven, so she has shown me much love. But a person who is forgiven little shows only little love.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to the woman, “Your sins are forgiven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men at the table said among themselves, “Who is this man, that he goes around forgiving sins?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jesus said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you; go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon afterward Jesus began a tour of the nearby towns and villages, preaching and announcing the Good News about the Kingdom of God. He took his twelve disciples with him,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with some women who had been cured of evil spirits and diseases. Among them were Mary Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven demons;
speaker: Narrator

text: Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod’s business manager; Susanna; and many others who were contributing from their own resources to support Jesus and his disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus told a story in the form of a parable to a large crowd that had gathered from many towns to hear him:
speaker: Narrator

text: “A farmer went out to plant his seed. As he scattered it across his field, some seed fell on a footpath, where it was stepped on, and the birds ate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other seed fell among rocks. It began to grow, but the plant soon wilted and died for lack of moisture.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other seed fell among thorns that grew up with it and choked out the tender plants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still other seed fell on fertile soil. This seed grew and produced a crop that was a hundred times as much as had been planted!” When he had said this, he called out, “Anyone with ears to hear should listen and understand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His disciples asked him what this parable meant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He replied, “You are permitted to understand the secrets of the Kingdom of God. But I use parables to teach the others so that the Scriptures might be fulfilled:
‘When they look, they won’t really see.
    When they hear, they won’t understand.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the meaning of the parable: The seed is God’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seeds that fell on the footpath represent those who hear the message, only to have the devil come and take it away from their hearts and prevent them from believing and being saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seeds on the rocky soil represent those who hear the message and receive it with joy. But since they don’t have deep roots, they believe for a while, then they fall away when they face temptation.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seeds that fell among the thorns represent those who hear the message, but all too quickly the message is crowded out by the cares and riches and pleasures of this life. And so they never grow into maturity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the seeds that fell on the good soil represent honest, good-hearted people who hear God’s word, cling to it, and patiently produce a huge harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No one lights a lamp and then covers it with a bowl or hides it under a bed. A lamp is placed on a stand, where its light can be seen by all who enter the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all that is secret will eventually be brought into the open, and everything that is concealed will be brought to light and made known to all.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So pay attention to how you hear. To those who listen to my teaching, more understanding will be given. But for those who are not listening, even what they think they understand will be taken away from them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus’ mother and brothers came to see him, but they couldn’t get to him because of the crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone told Jesus, “Your mother and your brothers are standing outside, and they want to see you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “My mother and my brothers are all those who hear God’s word and obey it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus said to his disciples, “Let’s cross to the other side of the lake.” So they got into a boat and started out.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they sailed across, Jesus settled down for a nap. But soon a fierce storm came down on the lake. The boat was filling with water, and they were in real danger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The disciples went and woke him up, shouting, “Master, Master, we’re going to drown!”
When Jesus woke up, he rebuked the wind and the raging waves. Suddenly the storm stopped and all was calm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he asked them, “Where is your faith?”
The disciples were terrified and amazed. “Who is this man?” they asked each other. “When he gives a command, even the wind and waves obey him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they arrived in the region of the Gerasenes, across the lake from Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus was climbing out of the boat, a man who was possessed by demons came out to meet him. For a long time he had been homeless and naked, living in the tombs outside the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he saw Jesus, he shrieked and fell down in front of him. Then he screamed, “Why are you interfering with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? Please, I beg you, don’t torture me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For Jesus had already commanded the evil spirit to come out of him. This spirit had often taken control of the man. Even when he was placed under guard and put in chains and shackles, he simply broke them and rushed out into the wilderness, completely under the demon’s power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus demanded, “What is your name?”
“Legion,” he replied, for he was filled with many demons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The demons kept begging Jesus not to send them into the bottomless pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There happened to be a large herd of pigs feeding on the hillside nearby, and the demons begged him to let them enter into the pigs.
So Jesus gave them permission.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the demons came out of the man and entered the pigs, and the entire herd plunged down the steep hillside into the lake and drowned.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the herdsmen saw it, they fled to the nearby town and the surrounding countryside, spreading the news as they ran.
speaker: Narrator

text: People rushed out to see what had happened. A crowd soon gathered around Jesus, and they saw the man who had been freed from the demons. He was sitting at Jesus’ feet, fully clothed and perfectly sane, and they were all afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those who had seen what happened told the others how the demon-possessed man had been healed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And all the people in the region of the Gerasenes begged Jesus to go away and leave them alone, for a great wave of fear swept over them.
So Jesus returned to the boat and left, crossing back to the other side of the lake.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who had been freed from the demons begged to go with him. But Jesus sent him home, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, go back to your family, and tell them everything God has done for you.” So he went all through the town proclaiming the great things Jesus had done for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the other side of the lake the crowds welcomed Jesus, because they had been waiting for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a man named Jairus, a leader of the local synagogue, came and fell at Jesus’ feet, pleading with him to come home with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His only daughter, who was about twelve years old, was dying.
As Jesus went with him, he was surrounded by the crowds.
speaker: Narrator

text: A woman in the crowd had suffered for twelve years with constant bleeding, and she could find no cure.
speaker: Narrator

text: Coming up behind Jesus, she touched the fringe of his robe. Immediately, the bleeding stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who touched me?” Jesus asked.
Everyone denied it, and Peter said, “Master, this whole crowd is pressing up against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus said, “Someone deliberately touched me, for I felt healing power go out from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman realized that she could not stay hidden, she began to tremble and fell to her knees in front of him. The whole crowd heard her explain why she had touched him and that she had been immediately healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Daughter,” he said to her, “your faith has made you well. Go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking to her, a messenger arrived from the home of Jairus, the leader of the synagogue. He told him, “Your daughter is dead. There’s no use troubling the Teacher now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Jesus heard what had happened, he said to Jairus, “Don’t be afraid. Just have faith, and she will be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived at the house, Jesus wouldn’t let anyone go in with him except Peter, John, James, and the little girl’s father and mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house was filled with people weeping and wailing, but he said, “Stop the weeping! She isn’t dead; she’s only asleep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the crowd laughed at him because they all knew she had died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus took her by the hand and said in a loud voice, “My child, get up!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And at that moment her life returned, and she immediately stood up! Then Jesus told them to give her something to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her parents were overwhelmed, but Jesus insisted that they not tell anyone what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus called together his twelve disciples and gave them power and authority to cast out all demons and to heal all diseases.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent them out to tell everyone about the Kingdom of God and to heal the sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take nothing for your journey,” he instructed them. “Don’t take a walking stick, a traveler’s bag, food, money, or even a change of clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever you go, stay in the same house until you leave town.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if a town refuses to welcome you, shake its dust from your feet as you leave to show that you have abandoned those people to their fate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they began their circuit of the villages, preaching the Good News and healing the sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Herod Antipas, the ruler of Galilee, heard about everything Jesus was doing, he was puzzled. Some were saying that John the Baptist had been raised from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Others thought Jesus was Elijah or one of the other prophets risen from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I beheaded John,” Herod said, “so who is this man about whom I hear such stories?” And he kept trying to see him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the apostles returned, they told Jesus everything they had done. Then he slipped quietly away with them toward the town of Bethsaida.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the crowds found out where he was going, and they followed him. He welcomed them and taught them about the Kingdom of God, and he healed those who were sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Late in the afternoon the twelve disciples came to him and said, “Send the crowds away to the nearby villages and farms, so they can find food and lodging for the night. There is nothing to eat here in this remote place.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Jesus said, “You feed them.”
“But we have only five loaves of bread and two fish,” they answered. “Or are you expecting us to go and buy enough food for this whole crowd?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For there were about 5,000 men there.
Jesus replied, “Tell them to sit down in groups of about fifty each.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people all sat down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus took the five loaves and two fish, looked up toward heaven, and blessed them. Then, breaking the loaves into pieces, he kept giving the bread and fish to the disciples so they could distribute it to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all ate as much as they wanted, and afterward, the disciples picked up twelve baskets of leftovers!
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus left the crowds to pray alone. Only his disciples were with him, and he asked them, “Who do people say I am?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Well,” they replied, “some say John the Baptist, some say Elijah, and others say you are one of the other ancient prophets risen from the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he asked them, “But who do you say I am?”
Peter replied, “You are the Messiah sent from God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus warned his disciples not to tell anyone who he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Son of Man must suffer many terrible things,” he said. “He will be rejected by the elders, the leading priests, and the teachers of religious law. He will be killed, but on the third day he will be raised from the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to the crowd, “If any of you wants to be my follower, you must give up your own way, take up your cross daily, and follow me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you try to hang on to your life, you will lose it. But if you give up your life for my sake, you will save it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what do you benefit if you gain the whole world but are yourself lost or destroyed?
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone is ashamed of me and my message, the Son of Man will be ashamed of that person when he returns in his glory and in the glory of the Father and the holy angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you the truth, some standing here right now will not die before they see the Kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: About eight days later Jesus took Peter, John, and James up on a mountain to pray.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as he was praying, the appearance of his face was transformed, and his clothes became dazzling white.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, two men, Moses and Elijah, appeared and began talking with Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were glorious to see. And they were speaking about his exodus from this world, which was about to be fulfilled in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter and the others had fallen asleep. When they woke up, they saw Jesus’ glory and the two men standing with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Moses and Elijah were starting to leave, Peter, not even knowing what he was saying, blurted out, “Master, it’s wonderful for us to be here! Let’s make three shelters as memorials—one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But even as he was saying this, a cloud overshadowed them, and terror gripped them as the cloud covered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a voice from the cloud said, “This is my Son, my Chosen One. Listen to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the voice finished, Jesus was there alone. They didn’t tell anyone at that time what they had seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, after they had come down the mountain, a large crowd met Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man in the crowd called out to him, “Teacher, I beg you to look at my son, my only child.
speaker: Narrator

text: An evil spirit keeps seizing him, making him scream. It throws him into convulsions so that he foams at the mouth. It batters him and hardly ever leaves him alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: I begged your disciples to cast out the spirit, but they couldn’t do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, “You faithless and corrupt people! How long must I be with you and put up with you?” Then he said to the man, “Bring your son here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the boy came forward, the demon knocked him to the ground and threw him into a violent convulsion. But Jesus rebuked the evil spirit and healed the boy. Then he gave him back to his father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awe gripped the people as they saw this majestic display of God’s power.
While everyone was marveling at everything he was doing, Jesus said to his disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen to me and remember what I say. The Son of Man is going to be betrayed into the hands of his enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they didn’t know what he meant. Its significance was hidden from them, so they couldn’t understand it, and they were afraid to ask him about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his disciples began arguing about which of them was the greatest.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus knew their thoughts, so he brought a little child to his side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to them, “Anyone who welcomes a little child like this on my behalf welcomes me, and anyone who welcomes me also welcomes my Father who sent me. Whoever is the least among you is the greatest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: John said to Jesus, “Master, we saw someone using your name to cast out demons, but we told him to stop because he isn’t in our group.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus said, “Don’t stop him! Anyone who is not against you is for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the time drew near for him to ascend to heaven, Jesus resolutely set out for Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers ahead to a Samaritan village to prepare for his arrival.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of the village did not welcome Jesus because he was on his way to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When James and John saw this, they said to Jesus, “Lord, should we call down fire from heaven to burn them up?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus turned and rebuked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went on to another village.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were walking along, someone said to Jesus, “I will follow you wherever you go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus replied, “Foxes have dens to live in, and birds have nests, but the Son of Man has no place even to lay his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to another person, “Come, follow me.”
The man agreed, but he said, “Lord, first let me return home and bury my father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus told him, “Let the spiritually dead bury their own dead! Your duty is to go and preach about the Kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Another said, “Yes, Lord, I will follow you, but first let me say good-bye to my family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus told him, “Anyone who puts a hand to the plow and then looks back is not fit for the Kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord now chose seventy-two other disciples and sent them ahead in pairs to all the towns and places he planned to visit.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were his instructions to them: “The harvest is great, but the workers are few. So pray to the Lord who is in charge of the harvest; ask him to send more workers into his fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now go, and remember that I am sending you out as lambs among wolves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t take any money with you, nor a traveler’s bag, nor an extra pair of sandals. And don’t stop to greet anyone on the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever you enter someone’s home, first say, ‘May God’s peace be on this house.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If those who live there are peaceful, the blessing will stand; if they are not, the blessing will return to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t move around from home to home. Stay in one place, eating and drinking what they provide. Don’t hesitate to accept hospitality, because those who work deserve their pay.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you enter a town and it welcomes you, eat whatever is set before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heal the sick, and tell them, ‘The Kingdom of God is near you now.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a town refuses to welcome you, go out into its streets and say,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘We wipe even the dust of your town from our feet to show that we have abandoned you to your fate. And know this—the Kingdom of God is near!’
speaker: Narrator

text: I assure you, even wicked Sodom will be better off than such a town on judgment day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What sorrow awaits you, Korazin and Bethsaida! For if the miracles I did in you had been done in wicked Tyre and Sidon, their people would have repented of their sins long ago, clothing themselves in burlap and throwing ashes on their heads to show their remorse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, Tyre and Sidon will be better off on judgment day than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you people of Capernaum, will you be honored in heaven? No, you will go down to the place of the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to the disciples, “Anyone who accepts your message is also accepting me. And anyone who rejects you is rejecting me. And anyone who rejects me is rejecting God, who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the seventy-two disciples returned, they joyfully reported to him, “Lord, even the demons obey us when we use your name!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes,” he told them, “I saw Satan fall from heaven like lightning!
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I have given you authority over all the power of the enemy, and you can walk among snakes and scorpions and crush them. Nothing will injure you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t rejoice because evil spirits obey you; rejoice because your names are registered in heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that same time Jesus was filled with the joy of the Holy Spirit, and he said, “O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, thank you for hiding these things from those who think themselves wise and clever, and for revealing them to the childlike. Yes, Father, it pleased you to do it this way.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My Father has entrusted everything to me. No one truly knows the Son except the Father, and no one truly knows the Father except the Son and those to whom the Son chooses to reveal him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when they were alone, he turned to the disciples and said, “Blessed are the eyes that see what you have seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, many prophets and kings longed to see what you see, but they didn’t see it. And they longed to hear what you hear, but they didn’t hear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day an expert in religious law stood up to test Jesus by asking him this question: “Teacher, what should I do to inherit eternal life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “What does the law of Moses say? How do you read it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man answered, “‘You must love the Lord your God with all your heart, all your soul, all your strength, and all your mind.’ And, ‘Love your neighbor as yourself.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Right!” Jesus told him. “Do this and you will live!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man wanted to justify his actions, so he asked Jesus, “And who is my neighbor?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied with a story: “A Jewish man was traveling from Jerusalem down to Jericho, and he was attacked by bandits. They stripped him of his clothes, beat him up, and left him half dead beside the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: “By chance a priest came along. But when he saw the man lying there, he crossed to the other side of the road and passed him by.
speaker: Narrator

text: A Temple assistant walked over and looked at him lying there, but he also passed by on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then a despised Samaritan came along, and when he saw the man, he felt compassion for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Going over to him, the Samaritan soothed his wounds with olive oil and wine and bandaged them. Then he put the man on his own donkey and took him to an inn, where he took care of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day he handed the innkeeper two silver coins, telling him, ‘Take care of this man. If his bill runs higher than this, I’ll pay you the next time I’m here.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now which of these three would you say was a neighbor to the man who was attacked by bandits?” Jesus asked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man replied, “The one who showed him mercy.”
Then Jesus said, “Yes, now go and do the same.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus and the disciples continued on their way to Jerusalem, they came to a certain village where a woman named Martha welcomed him into her home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her sister, Mary, sat at the Lord’s feet, listening to what he taught.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Martha was distracted by the big dinner she was preparing. She came to Jesus and said, “Lord, doesn’t it seem unfair to you that my sister just sits here while I do all the work? Tell her to come and help me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to her, “My dear Martha, you are worried and upset over all these details!
speaker: Narrator

text: There is only one thing worth being concerned about. Mary has discovered it, and it will not be taken away from her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Once Jesus was in a certain place praying. As he finished, one of his disciples came to him and said, “Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his disciples.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus said, “This is how you should pray:
“Father, may your name be kept holy.
    May your Kingdom come soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give us each day the food we need,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and forgive us our sins,
    as we forgive those who sin against us.
And don’t let us yield to temptation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, teaching them more about prayer, he used this story: “Suppose you went to a friend’s house at midnight, wanting to borrow three loaves of bread. You say to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘A friend of mine has just arrived for a visit, and I have nothing for him to eat.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And suppose he calls out from his bedroom, ‘Don’t bother me. The door is locked for the night, and my family and I are all in bed. I can’t help you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But I tell you this—though he won’t do it for friendship’s sake, if you keep knocking long enough, he will get up and give you whatever you need because of your shameless persistence.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And so I tell you, keep on asking, and you will receive what you ask for. Keep on seeking, and you will find. Keep on knocking, and the door will be opened to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For everyone who asks, receives. Everyone who seeks, finds. And to everyone who knocks, the door will be opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You fathers—if your children ask for a fish, do you give them a snake instead?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or if they ask for an egg, do you give them a scorpion? Of course not!
speaker: Narrator

text: So if you sinful people know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus cast out a demon from a man who couldn’t speak, and when the demon was gone, the man began to speak. The crowds were amazed,
speaker: Narrator

text: but some of them said, “No wonder he can cast out demons. He gets his power from Satan, the prince of demons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Others, trying to test Jesus, demanded that he show them a miraculous sign from heaven to prove his authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: He knew their thoughts, so he said, “Any kingdom divided by civil war is doomed. A family splintered by feuding will fall apart.
speaker: Narrator

text: You say I am empowered by Satan. But if Satan is divided and fighting against himself, how can his kingdom survive?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if I am empowered by Satan, what about your own exorcists? They cast out demons, too, so they will condemn you for what you have said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I am casting out demons by the power of God, then the Kingdom of God has arrived among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when a strong man is fully armed and guards his palace, his possessions are safe—
speaker: Narrator

text: until someone even stronger attacks and overpowers him, strips him of his weapons, and carries off his belongings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Anyone who isn’t with me opposes me, and anyone who isn’t working with me is actually working against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When an evil spirit leaves a person, it goes into the desert, searching for rest. But when it finds none, it says, ‘I will return to the person I came from.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So it returns and finds that its former home is all swept and in order.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the spirit finds seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they all enter the person and live there. And so that person is worse off than before.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was speaking, a woman in the crowd called out, “God bless your mother—the womb from which you came, and the breasts that nursed you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “But even more blessed are all who hear the word of God and put it into practice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the crowd pressed in on Jesus, he said, “This evil generation keeps asking me to show them a miraculous sign. But the only sign I will give them is the sign of Jonah.
speaker: Narrator

text: What happened to him was a sign to the people of Nineveh that God had sent him. What happens to the Son of Man will be a sign to these people that he was sent by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The queen of Sheba will stand up against this generation on judgment day and condemn it, for she came from a distant land to hear the wisdom of Solomon. Now someone greater than Solomon is here—but you refuse to listen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Nineveh will also stand up against this generation on judgment day and condemn it, for they repented of their sins at the preaching of Jonah. Now someone greater than Jonah is here—but you refuse to repent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No one lights a lamp and then hides it or puts it under a basket. Instead, a lamp is placed on a stand, where its light can be seen by all who enter the house.
speaker: Narrator
