text: “Your eye is like a lamp that provides light for your body. When your eye is healthy, your whole body is filled with light. But when it is unhealthy, your body is filled with darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make sure that the light you think you have is not actually darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are filled with light, with no dark corners, then your whole life will be radiant, as though a floodlight were filling you with light.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus was speaking, one of the Pharisees invited him home for a meal. So he went in and took his place at the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: His host was amazed to see that he sat down to eat without first performing the hand-washing ceremony required by Jewish custom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “You Pharisees are so careful to clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but inside you are filthy—full of greed and wickedness!
speaker: Narrator

text: Fools! Didn’t God make the inside as well as the outside?
speaker: Narrator

text: So clean the inside by giving gifts to the poor, and you will be clean all over.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What sorrow awaits you Pharisees! For you are careful to tithe even the tiniest income from your herb gardens, but you ignore justice and the love of God. You should tithe, yes, but do not neglect the more important things.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What sorrow awaits you Pharisees! For you love to sit in the seats of honor in the synagogues and receive respectful greetings as you walk in the marketplaces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, what sorrow awaits you! For you are like hidden graves in a field. People walk over them without knowing the corruption they are stepping on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Teacher,” said an expert in religious law, “you have insulted us, too, in what you just said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes,” said Jesus, “what sorrow also awaits you experts in religious law! For you crush people with unbearable religious demands, and you never lift a finger to ease the burden.
speaker: Narrator

text: What sorrow awaits you! For you build monuments for the prophets your own ancestors killed long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in fact, you stand as witnesses who agree with what your ancestors did. They killed the prophets, and you join in their crime by building the monuments!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what God in his wisdom said about you: ‘I will send prophets and apostles to them, but they will kill some and persecute the others.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “As a result, this generation will be held responsible for the murder of all God’s prophets from the creation of the world—
speaker: Narrator

text: from the murder of Abel to the murder of Zechariah, who was killed between the altar and the sanctuary. Yes, it will certainly be charged against this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What sorrow awaits you experts in religious law! For you remove the key to knowledge from the people. You don’t enter the Kingdom yourselves, and you prevent others from entering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus was leaving, the teachers of religious law and the Pharisees became hostile and tried to provoke him with many questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: They wanted to trap him into saying something they could use against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the crowds grew until thousands were milling about and stepping on each other. Jesus turned first to his disciples and warned them, “Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees—their hypocrisy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time is coming when everything that is covered up will be revealed, and all that is secret will be made known to all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever you have said in the dark will be heard in the light, and what you have whispered behind closed doors will be shouted from the housetops for all to hear!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Dear friends, don’t be afraid of those who want to kill your body; they cannot do any more to you after that.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I’ll tell you whom to fear. Fear God, who has the power to kill you and then throw you into hell. Yes, he’s the one to fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What is the price of five sparrows—two copper coins? Yet God does not forget a single one of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the very hairs on your head are all numbered. So don’t be afraid; you are more valuable to God than a whole flock of sparrows.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell you the truth, everyone who acknowledges me publicly here on earth, the Son of Man will also acknowledge in the presence of God’s angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone who denies me here on earth will be denied before God’s angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who speaks against the Son of Man can be forgiven, but anyone who blasphemes the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And when you are brought to trial in the synagogues and before rulers and authorities, don’t worry about how to defend yourself or what to say,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Holy Spirit will teach you at that time what needs to be said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then someone called from the crowd, “Teacher, please tell my brother to divide our father’s estate with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “Friend, who made me a judge over you to decide such things as that?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Beware! Guard against every kind of greed. Life is not measured by how much you own.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told them a story: “A rich man had a fertile farm that produced fine crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to himself, ‘What should I do? I don’t have room for all my crops.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, ‘I know! I’ll tear down my barns and build bigger ones. Then I’ll have room enough to store all my wheat and other goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I’ll sit back and say to myself, “My friend, you have enough stored away for years to come. Now take it easy! Eat, drink, and be merry!”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But God said to him, ‘You fool! You will die this very night. Then who will get everything you worked for?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes, a person is a fool to store up earthly wealth but not have a rich relationship with God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, turning to his disciples, Jesus said, “That is why I tell you not to worry about everyday life—whether you have enough food to eat or enough clothes to wear.
speaker: Narrator

text: For life is more than food, and your body more than clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at the ravens. They don’t plant or harvest or store food in barns, for God feeds them. And you are far more valuable to him than any birds!
speaker: Narrator

text: Can all your worries add a single moment to your life?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if worry can’t accomplish a little thing like that, what’s the use of worrying over bigger things?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look at the lilies and how they grow. They don’t work or make their clothing, yet Solomon in all his glory was not dressed as beautifully as they are.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if God cares so wonderfully for flowers that are here today and thrown into the fire tomorrow, he will certainly care for you. Why do you have so little faith?
speaker: Narrator

text: “And don’t be concerned about what to eat and what to drink. Don’t worry about such things.
speaker: Narrator

text: These things dominate the thoughts of unbelievers all over the world, but your Father already knows your needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seek the Kingdom of God above all else, and he will give you everything you need.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So don’t be afraid, little flock. For it gives your Father great happiness to give you the Kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sell your possessions and give to those in need. This will store up treasure for you in heaven! And the purses of heaven never get old or develop holes. Your treasure will be safe; no thief can steal it and no moth can destroy it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever your treasure is, there the desires of your heart will also be.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be dressed for service and keep your lamps burning,
speaker: Narrator

text: as though you were waiting for your master to return from the wedding feast. Then you will be ready to open the door and let him in the moment he arrives and knocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servants who are ready and waiting for his return will be rewarded. I tell you the truth, he himself will seat them, put on an apron, and serve them as they sit and eat!
speaker: Narrator

text: He may come in the middle of the night or just before dawn. But whenever he comes, he will reward the servants who are ready.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Understand this: If a homeowner knew exactly when a burglar was coming, he would not permit his house to be broken into.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also must be ready all the time, for the Son of Man will come when least expected.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter asked, “Lord, is that illustration just for us or for everyone?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord replied, “A faithful, sensible servant is one to whom the master can give the responsibility of managing his other household servants and feeding them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the master returns and finds that the servant has done a good job, there will be a reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you the truth, the master will put that servant in charge of all he owns.
speaker: Narrator

text: But what if the servant thinks, ‘My master won’t be back for a while,’ and he begins beating the other servants, partying, and getting drunk?
speaker: Narrator

text: The master will return unannounced and unexpected, and he will cut the servant in pieces and banish him with the unfaithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And a servant who knows what the master wants, but isn’t prepared and doesn’t carry out those instructions, will be severely punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone who does not know, and then does something wrong, will be punished only lightly. When someone has been given much, much will be required in return; and when someone has been entrusted with much, even more will be required.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have come to set the world on fire, and I wish it were already burning!
speaker: Narrator

text: I have a terrible baptism of suffering ahead of me, and I am under a heavy burden until it is accomplished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you think I have come to bring peace to the earth? No, I have come to divide people against each other!
speaker: Narrator

text: From now on families will be split apart, three in favor of me, and two against—or two in favor and three against.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Jesus turned to the crowd and said, “When you see clouds beginning to form in the west, you say, ‘Here comes a shower.’ And you are right.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the south wind blows, you say, ‘Today will be a scorcher.’ And it is.
speaker: Narrator

text: You fools! You know how to interpret the weather signs of the earth and sky, but you don’t know how to interpret the present times.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why can’t you decide for yourselves what is right?
speaker: Narrator

text: When you are on the way to court with your accuser, try to settle the matter before you get there. Otherwise, your accuser may drag you before the judge, who will hand you over to an officer, who will throw you into prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if that happens, you won’t be free again until you have paid the very last penny.”
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time Jesus was informed that Pilate had murdered some people from Galilee as they were offering sacrifices at the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do you think those Galileans were worse sinners than all the other people from Galilee?” Jesus asked. “Is that why they suffered?
speaker: Narrator

text: Not at all! And you will perish, too, unless you repent of your sins and turn to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what about the eighteen people who died when the tower in Siloam fell on them? Were they the worst sinners in Jerusalem?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, and I tell you again that unless you repent, you will perish, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told this story: “A man planted a fig tree in his garden and came again and again to see if there was any fruit on it, but he was always disappointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, he said to his gardener, ‘I’ve waited three years, and there hasn’t been a single fig! Cut it down. It’s just taking up space in the garden.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The gardener answered, ‘Sir, give it one more chance. Leave it another year, and I’ll give it special attention and plenty of fertilizer.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we get figs next year, fine. If not, then you can cut it down.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: One Sabbath day as Jesus was teaching in a synagogue,
speaker: Narrator

text: he saw a woman who had been crippled by an evil spirit. She had been bent double for eighteen years and was unable to stand up straight.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus saw her, he called her over and said, “Dear woman, you are healed of your sickness!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he touched her, and instantly she could stand straight. How she praised God!
speaker: Narrator

text: But the leader in charge of the synagogue was indignant that Jesus had healed her on the Sabbath day. “There are six days of the week for working,” he said to the crowd. “Come on those days to be healed, not on the Sabbath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord replied, “You hypocrites! Each of you works on the Sabbath day! Don’t you untie your ox or your donkey from its stall on the Sabbath and lead it out for water?
speaker: Narrator

text: This dear woman, a daughter of Abraham, has been held in bondage by Satan for eighteen years. Isn’t it right that she be released, even on the Sabbath?”
speaker: Narrator

text: This shamed his enemies, but all the people rejoiced at the wonderful things he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said, “What is the Kingdom of God like? How can I illustrate it?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is like a tiny mustard seed that a man planted in a garden; it grows and becomes a tree, and the birds make nests in its branches.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also asked, “What else is the Kingdom of God like?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is like the yeast a woman used in making bread. Even though she put only a little yeast in three measures of flour, it permeated every part of the dough.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus went through the towns and villages, teaching as he went, always pressing on toward Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Someone asked him, “Lord, will only a few be saved?”
He replied,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Work hard to enter the narrow door to God’s Kingdom, for many will try to enter but will fail.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the master of the house has locked the door, it will be too late. You will stand outside knocking and pleading, ‘Lord, open the door for us!’ But he will reply, ‘I don’t know you or where you come from.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will say, ‘But we ate and drank with you, and you taught in our streets.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And he will reply, ‘I tell you, I don’t know you or where you come from. Get away from me, all you who do evil.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, for you will see Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets in the Kingdom of God, but you will be thrown out.
speaker: Narrator

text: And people will come from all over the world—from east and west, north and south—to take their places in the Kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And note this: Some who seem least important now will be the greatest then, and some who are the greatest now will be least important then.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time some Pharisees said to him, “Get away from here if you want to live! Herod Antipas wants to kill you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “Go tell that fox that I will keep on casting out demons and healing people today and tomorrow; and the third day I will accomplish my purpose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, today, tomorrow, and the next day I must proceed on my way. For it wouldn’t do for a prophet of God to be killed except in Jerusalem!
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones God’s messengers! How often I have wanted to gather your children together as a hen protects her chicks beneath her wings, but you wouldn’t let me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, look, your house is abandoned. And you will never see me again until you say, ‘Blessings on the one who comes in the name of the Lord!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: One Sabbath day Jesus went to eat dinner in the home of a leader of the Pharisees, and the people were watching him closely.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man there whose arms and legs were swollen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus asked the Pharisees and experts in religious law, “Is it permitted in the law to heal people on the Sabbath day, or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they refused to answer, Jesus touched the sick man and healed him and sent him away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned to them and said, “Which of you doesn’t work on the Sabbath? If your son or your cow falls into a pit, don’t you rush to get him out?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again they could not answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus noticed that all who had come to the dinner were trying to sit in the seats of honor near the head of the table, he gave them this advice:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you are invited to a wedding feast, don’t sit in the seat of honor. What if someone who is more distinguished than you has also been invited?
speaker: Narrator

text: The host will come and say, ‘Give this person your seat.’ Then you will be embarrassed, and you will have to take whatever seat is left at the foot of the table!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Instead, take the lowest place at the foot of the table. Then when your host sees you, he will come and say, ‘Friend, we have a better place for you!’ Then you will be honored in front of all the other guests.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned to his host. “When you put on a luncheon or a banquet,” he said, “don’t invite your friends, brothers, relatives, and rich neighbors. For they will invite you back, and that will be your only reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, and the blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then at the resurrection of the righteous, God will reward you for inviting those who could not repay you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hearing this, a man sitting at the table with Jesus exclaimed, “What a blessing it will be to attend a banquet in the Kingdom of God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied with this story: “A man prepared a great feast and sent out many invitations.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the banquet was ready, he sent his servant to tell the guests, ‘Come, the banquet is ready.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But they all began making excuses. One said, ‘I have just bought a field and must inspect it. Please excuse me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Another said, ‘I have just bought five pairs of oxen, and I want to try them out. Please excuse me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Another said, ‘I just got married, so I can’t come.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The servant returned and told his master what they had said. His master was furious and said, ‘Go quickly into the streets and alleys of the town and invite the poor, the crippled, the blind, and the lame.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After the servant had done this, he reported, ‘There is still room for more.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So his master said, ‘Go out into the country lanes and behind the hedges and urge anyone you find to come, so that the house will be full.
speaker: Narrator

text: For none of those I first invited will get even the smallest taste of my banquet.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: A large crowd was following Jesus. He turned around and said to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you want to be my disciple, you must, by comparison, hate everyone else—your father and mother, wife and children, brothers and sisters—yes, even your own life. Otherwise, you cannot be my disciple.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you do not carry your own cross and follow me, you cannot be my disciple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But don’t begin until you count the cost. For who would begin construction of a building without first calculating the cost to see if there is enough money to finish it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, you might complete only the foundation before running out of money, and then everyone would laugh at you.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would say, ‘There’s the person who started that building and couldn’t afford to finish it!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Or what king would go to war against another king without first sitting down with his counselors to discuss whether his army of 10,000 could defeat the 20,000 soldiers marching against him?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if he can’t, he will send a delegation to discuss terms of peace while the enemy is still far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you cannot become my disciple without giving up everything you own.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Salt is good for seasoning. But if it loses its flavor, how do you make it salty again?
speaker: Narrator

text: Flavorless salt is good neither for the soil nor for the manure pile. It is thrown away. Anyone with ears to hear should listen and understand!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Tax collectors and other notorious sinners often came to listen to Jesus teach.
speaker: Narrator

text: This made the Pharisees and teachers of religious law complain that he was associating with such sinful people—even eating with them!
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jesus told them this story:
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man has a hundred sheep and one of them gets lost, what will he do? Won’t he leave the ninety-nine others in the wilderness and go to search for the one that is lost until he finds it?
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he has found it, he will joyfully carry it home on his shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrives, he will call together his friends and neighbors, saying, ‘Rejoice with me because I have found my lost sheep.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, there is more joy in heaven over one lost sinner who repents and returns to God than over ninety-nine others who are righteous and haven’t strayed away!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Or suppose a woman has ten silver coins and loses one. Won’t she light a lamp and sweep the entire house and search carefully until she finds it?
speaker: Narrator

text: And when she finds it, she will call in her friends and neighbors and say, ‘Rejoice with me because I have found my lost coin.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, there is joy in the presence of God’s angels when even one sinner repents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: To illustrate the point further, Jesus told them this story: “A man had two sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The younger son told his father, ‘I want my share of your estate now before you die.’ So his father agreed to divide his wealth between his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A few days later this younger son packed all his belongings and moved to a distant land, and there he wasted all his money in wild living.
speaker: Narrator

text: About the time his money ran out, a great famine swept over the land, and he began to starve.
speaker: Narrator

text: He persuaded a local farmer to hire him, and the man sent him into his fields to feed the pigs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man became so hungry that even the pods he was feeding the pigs looked good to him. But no one gave him anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When he finally came to his senses, he said to himself, ‘At home even the hired servants have food enough to spare, and here I am dying of hunger!
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go home to my father and say, “Father, I have sinned against both heaven and you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I am no longer worthy of being called your son. Please take me on as a hired servant.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So he returned home to his father. And while he was still a long way off, his father saw him coming. Filled with love and compassion, he ran to his son, embraced him, and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His son said to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against both heaven and you, and I am no longer worthy of being called your son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But his father said to the servants, ‘Quick! Bring the finest robe in the house and put it on him. Get a ring for his finger and sandals for his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: And kill the calf we have been fattening. We must celebrate with a feast,
speaker: Narrator

text: for this son of mine was dead and has now returned to life. He was lost, but now he is found.’ So the party began.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Meanwhile, the older son was in the fields working. When he returned home, he heard music and dancing in the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he asked one of the servants what was going on.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Your brother is back,’ he was told, ‘and your father has killed the fattened calf. We are celebrating because of his safe return.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The older brother was angry and wouldn’t go in. His father came out and begged him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he replied, ‘All these years I’ve slaved for you and never once refused to do a single thing you told me to. And in all that time you never gave me even one young goat for a feast with my friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet when this son of yours comes back after squandering your money on prostitutes, you celebrate by killing the fattened calf!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “His father said to him, ‘Look, dear son, you have always stayed by me, and everything I have is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: We had to celebrate this happy day. For your brother was dead and has come back to life! He was lost, but now he is found!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told this story to his disciples: “There was a certain rich man who had a manager handling his affairs. One day a report came that the manager was wasting his employer’s money.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the employer called him in and said, ‘What’s this I hear about you? Get your report in order, because you are going to be fired.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The manager thought to himself, ‘Now what? My boss has fired me. I don’t have the strength to dig ditches, and I’m too proud to beg.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ah, I know how to ensure that I’ll have plenty of friends who will give me a home when I am fired.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So he invited each person who owed money to his employer to come and discuss the situation. He asked the first one, ‘How much do you owe him?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The man replied, ‘I owe him 800 gallons of olive oil.’ So the manager told him, ‘Take the bill and quickly change it to 400 gallons.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘And how much do you owe my employer?’ he asked the next man. ‘I owe him 1,000 bushels of wheat,’ was the reply. ‘Here,’ the manager said, ‘take the bill and change it to 800 bushels.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The rich man had to admire the dishonest rascal for being so shrewd. And it is true that the children of this world are more shrewd in dealing with the world around them than are the children of the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here’s the lesson: Use your worldly resources to benefit others and make friends. Then, when your possessions are gone, they will welcome you to an eternal home.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you are faithful in little things, you will be faithful in large ones. But if you are dishonest in little things, you won’t be honest with greater responsibilities.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you are untrustworthy about worldly wealth, who will trust you with the true riches of heaven?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you are not faithful with other people’s things, why should you be trusted with things of your own?
speaker: Narrator

text: “No one can serve two masters. For you will hate one and love the other; you will be devoted to one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and be enslaved to money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisees, who dearly loved their money, heard all this and scoffed at him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to them, “You like to appear righteous in public, but God knows your hearts. What this world honors is detestable in the sight of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Until John the Baptist, the law of Moses and the messages of the prophets were your guides. But now the Good News of the Kingdom of God is preached, and everyone is eager to get in.
speaker: Narrator

text: But that doesn’t mean that the law has lost its force. It is easier for heaven and earth to disappear than for the smallest point of God’s law to be overturned.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For example, a man who divorces his wife and marries someone else commits adultery. And anyone who marries a woman divorced from her husband commits adultery.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, “There was a certain rich man who was splendidly clothed in purple and fine linen and who lived each day in luxury.
speaker: Narrator

text: At his gate lay a poor man named Lazarus who was covered with sores.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Lazarus lay there longing for scraps from the rich man’s table, the dogs would come and lick his open sores.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Finally, the poor man died and was carried by the angels to sit beside Abraham at the heavenly banquet. The rich man also died and was buried,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he went to the place of the dead. There, in torment, he saw Abraham in the far distance with Lazarus at his side.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The rich man shouted, ‘Father Abraham, have some pity! Send Lazarus over here to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue. I am in anguish in these flames.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But Abraham said to him, ‘Son, remember that during your lifetime you had everything you wanted, and Lazarus had nothing. So now he is here being comforted, and you are in anguish.
speaker: Narrator

text: And besides, there is a great chasm separating us. No one can cross over to you from here, and no one can cross over to us from there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the rich man said, ‘Please, Father Abraham, at least send him to my father’s home.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have five brothers, and I want him to warn them so they don’t end up in this place of torment.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But Abraham said, ‘Moses and the prophets have warned them. Your brothers can read what they wrote.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The rich man replied, ‘No, Father Abraham! But if someone is sent to them from the dead, then they will repent of their sins and turn to God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But Abraham said, ‘If they won’t listen to Moses and the prophets, they won’t be persuaded even if someone rises from the dead.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus said to his disciples, “There will always be temptations to sin, but what sorrow awaits the person who does the tempting!
speaker: Narrator

text: It would be better to be thrown into the sea with a millstone hung around your neck than to cause one of these little ones to fall into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So watch yourselves!
“If another believer sins, rebuke that person; then if there is repentance, forgive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if that person wrongs you seven times a day and each time turns again and asks forgiveness, you must forgive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The apostles said to the Lord, “Show us how to increase our faith.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered, “If you had faith even as small as a mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree, ‘May you be uprooted and be planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you!
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a servant comes in from plowing or taking care of sheep, does his master say, ‘Come in and eat with me’?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, he says, ‘Prepare my meal, put on your apron, and serve me while I eat. Then you can eat later.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And does the master thank the servant for doing what he was told to do? Of course not.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, when you obey me you should say, ‘We are unworthy servants who have simply done our duty.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus continued on toward Jerusalem, he reached the border between Galilee and Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he entered a village there, ten men with leprosy stood at a distance,
speaker: Narrator

text: crying out, “Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked at them and said, “Go show yourselves to the priests.” And as they went, they were cleansed of their leprosy.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them, when he saw that he was healed, came back to Jesus, shouting, “Praise God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He fell to the ground at Jesus’ feet, thanking him for what he had done. This man was a Samaritan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus asked, “Didn’t I heal ten men? Where are the other nine?
speaker: Narrator

text: Has no one returned to give glory to God except this foreigner?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jesus said to the man, “Stand up and go. Your faith has healed you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
One day the Pharisees asked Jesus, “When will the Kingdom of God come?”
Jesus replied, “The Kingdom of God can’t be detected by visible signs.
speaker: Narrator

text: You won’t be able to say, ‘Here it is!’ or ‘It’s over there!’ For the Kingdom of God is already among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to his disciples, “The time is coming when you will long to see the day when the Son of Man returns, but you won’t see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will tell you, ‘Look, there is the Son of Man,’ or ‘Here he is,’ but don’t go out and follow them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as the lightning flashes and lights up the sky from one end to the other, so it will be on the day when the Son of Man comes.
speaker: Narrator

text: But first the Son of Man must suffer terribly and be rejected by this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Son of Man returns, it will be like it was in Noah’s day.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, the people enjoyed banquets and parties and weddings right up to the time Noah entered his boat and the flood came and destroyed them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And the world will be as it was in the days of Lot. People went about their daily business—eating and drinking, buying and selling, farming and building—
speaker: Narrator

text: until the morning Lot left Sodom. Then fire and burning sulfur rained down from heaven and destroyed them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, it will be ‘business as usual’ right up to the day when the Son of Man is revealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day a person out on the deck of a roof must not go down into the house to pack. A person out in the field must not return home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember what happened to Lot’s wife!
speaker: Narrator

text: If you cling to your life, you will lose it, and if you let your life go, you will save it.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night two people will be asleep in one bed; one will be taken, the other left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two women will be grinding flour together at the mill; one will be taken, the other left.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where will this happen, Lord?” the disciples asked.
Jesus replied, “Just as the gathering of vultures shows there is a carcass nearby, so these signs indicate that the end is near.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus told his disciples a story to show that they should always pray and never give up.
speaker: Narrator

text: “There was a judge in a certain city,” he said, “who neither feared God nor cared about people.
speaker: Narrator

text: A widow of that city came to him repeatedly, saying, ‘Give me justice in this dispute with my enemy.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The judge ignored her for a while, but finally he said to himself, ‘I don’t fear God or care about people,
speaker: Narrator

text: but this woman is driving me crazy. I’m going to see that she gets justice, because she is wearing me out with her constant requests!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Learn a lesson from this unjust judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even he rendered a just decision in the end. So don’t you think God will surely give justice to his chosen people who cry out to him day and night? Will he keep putting them off?
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, he will grant justice to them quickly! But when the Son of Man returns, how many will he find on the earth who have faith?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told this story to some who had great confidence in their own righteousness and scorned everyone else:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Two men went to the Temple to pray. One was a Pharisee, and the other was a despised tax collector.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed this prayer: ‘I thank you, God, that I am not like other people—cheaters, sinners, adulterers. I’m certainly not like that tax collector!
speaker: Narrator

text: I fast twice a week, and I give you a tenth of my income.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the tax collector stood at a distance and dared not even lift his eyes to heaven as he prayed. Instead, he beat his chest in sorrow, saying, ‘O God, be merciful to me, for I am a sinner.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, this sinner, not the Pharisee, returned home justified before God. For those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day some parents brought their little children to Jesus so he could touch and bless them. But when the disciples saw this, they scolded the parents for bothering him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus called for the children and said to the disciples, “Let the children come to me. Don’t stop them! For the Kingdom of God belongs to those who are like these children.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you the truth, anyone who doesn’t receive the Kingdom of God like a child will never enter it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Once a religious leader asked Jesus this question: “Good Teacher, what should I do to inherit eternal life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why do you call me good?” Jesus asked him. “Only God is truly good.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to answer your question, you know the commandments: ‘You must not commit adultery. You must not murder. You must not steal. You must not testify falsely. Honor your father and mother.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man replied, “I’ve obeyed all these commandments since I was young.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus heard his answer, he said, “There is still one thing you haven’t done. Sell all your possessions and give the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the man heard this he became very sad, for he was very rich.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus saw this, he said, “How hard it is for the rich to enter the Kingdom of God!
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the Kingdom of God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who heard this said, “Then who in the world can be saved?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “What is impossible for people is possible with God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter said, “We’ve left our homes to follow you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes,” Jesus replied, “and I assure you that everyone who has given up house or wife or brothers or parents or children, for the sake of the Kingdom of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: will be repaid many times over in this life, and will have eternal life in the world to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Taking the twelve disciples aside, Jesus said, “Listen, we’re going up to Jerusalem, where all the predictions of the prophets concerning the Son of Man will come true.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be handed over to the Romans, and he will be mocked, treated shamefully, and spit upon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will flog him with a whip and kill him, but on the third day he will rise again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they didn’t understand any of this. The significance of his words was hidden from them, and they failed to grasp what he was talking about.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus approached Jericho, a blind beggar was sitting beside the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard the noise of a crowd going past, he asked what was happening.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him that Jesus the Nazarene was going by.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he began shouting, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Be quiet!” the people in front yelled at him.
But he only shouted louder, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus heard him, he stopped and ordered that the man be brought to him. As the man came near, Jesus asked him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do you want me to do for you?”
“Lord,” he said, “I want to see!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jesus said, “All right, receive your sight! Your faith has healed you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instantly the man could see, and he followed Jesus, praising God. And all who saw it praised God, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus entered Jericho and made his way through the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man there named Zacchaeus. He was the chief tax collector in the region, and he had become very rich.
speaker: Narrator

text: He tried to get a look at Jesus, but he was too short to see over the crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he ran ahead and climbed a sycamore-fig tree beside the road, for Jesus was going to pass that way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus came by, he looked up at Zacchaeus and called him by name. “Zacchaeus!” he said. “Quick, come down! I must be a guest in your home today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Zacchaeus quickly climbed down and took Jesus to his house in great excitement and joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were displeased. “He has gone to be the guest of a notorious sinner,” they grumbled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Zacchaeus stood before the Lord and said, “I will give half my wealth to the poor, Lord, and if I have cheated people on their taxes, I will give them back four times as much!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus responded, “Salvation has come to this home today, for this man has shown himself to be a true son of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Son of Man came to seek and save those who are lost.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd was listening to everything Jesus said. And because he was nearing Jerusalem, he told them a story to correct the impression that the Kingdom of God would begin right away.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “A nobleman was called away to a distant empire to be crowned king and then return.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before he left, he called together ten of his servants and divided among them ten pounds of silver, saying, ‘Invest this for me while I am gone.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But his people hated him and sent a delegation after him to say, ‘We do not want him to be our king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “After he was crowned king, he returned and called in the servants to whom he had given the money. He wanted to find out what their profits were.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first servant reported, ‘Master, I invested your money and made ten times the original amount!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Well done!’ the king exclaimed. ‘You are a good servant. You have been faithful with the little I entrusted to you, so you will be governor of ten cities as your reward.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The next servant reported, ‘Master, I invested your money and made five times the original amount.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Well done!’ the king said. ‘You will be governor over five cities.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the third servant brought back only the original amount of money and said, ‘Master, I hid your money and kept it safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was afraid because you are a hard man to deal with, taking what isn’t yours and harvesting crops you didn’t plant.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You wicked servant!’ the king roared. ‘Your own words condemn you. If you knew that I’m a hard man who takes what isn’t mine and harvests crops I didn’t plant,
speaker: Narrator

text: why didn’t you deposit my money in the bank? At least I could have gotten some interest on it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then, turning to the others standing nearby, the king ordered, ‘Take the money from this servant, and give it to the one who has ten pounds.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But, master,’ they said, ‘he already has ten pounds!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Yes,’ the king replied, ‘and to those who use well what they are given, even more will be given. But from those who do nothing, even what little they have will be taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for these enemies of mine who didn’t want me to be their king—bring them in and execute them right here in front of me.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After telling this story, Jesus went on toward Jerusalem, walking ahead of his disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he came to the towns of Bethphage and Bethany on the Mount of Olives, he sent two disciples ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go into that village over there,” he told them. “As you enter it, you will see a young donkey tied there that no one has ever ridden. Untie it and bring it here.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone asks, ‘Why are you untying that colt?’ just say, ‘The Lord needs it.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went and found the colt, just as Jesus had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: And sure enough, as they were untying it, the owners asked them, “Why are you untying that colt?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the disciples simply replied, “The Lord needs it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought the colt to Jesus and threw their garments over it for him to ride on.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he rode along, the crowds spread out their garments on the road ahead of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he reached the place where the road started down the Mount of Olives, all of his followers began to shout and sing as they walked along, praising God for all the wonderful miracles they had seen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Blessings on the King who comes in the name of the Lord!
    Peace in heaven, and glory in highest heaven!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of the Pharisees among the crowd said, “Teacher, rebuke your followers for saying things like that!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “If they kept quiet, the stones along the road would burst into cheers!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But as he came closer to Jerusalem and saw the city ahead, he began to weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How I wish today that you of all people would understand the way to peace. But now it is too late, and peace is hidden from your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before long your enemies will build ramparts against your walls and encircle you and close in on you from every side.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will crush you into the ground, and your children with you. Your enemies will not leave a single stone in place, because you did not recognize it when God visited you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus entered the Temple and began to drive out the people selling animals for sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “The Scriptures declare, ‘My Temple will be a house of prayer,’ but you have turned it into a den of thieves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, he taught daily in the Temple, but the leading priests, the teachers of religious law, and the other leaders of the people began planning how to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they could think of nothing, because all the people hung on every word he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as Jesus was teaching the people and preaching the Good News in the Temple, the leading priests, the teachers of religious law, and the elders came up to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They demanded, “By what authority are you doing all these things? Who gave you the right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let me ask you a question first,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Did John’s authority to baptize come from heaven, or was it merely human?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They talked it over among themselves. “If we say it was from heaven, he will ask why we didn’t believe John.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we say it was merely human, the people will stone us because they are convinced John was a prophet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they finally replied that they didn’t know.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jesus responded, “Then I won’t tell you by what authority I do these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jesus turned to the people again and told them this story: “A man planted a vineyard, leased it to tenant farmers, and moved to another country to live for several years.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time of the grape harvest, he sent one of his servants to collect his share of the crop. But the farmers attacked the servant, beat him up, and sent him back empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the owner sent another servant, but they also insulted him, beat him up, and sent him away empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: A third man was sent, and they wounded him and chased him away.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘What will I do?’ the owner asked himself. ‘I know! I’ll send my cherished son. Surely they will respect him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But when the tenant farmers saw his son, they said to each other, ‘Here comes the heir to this estate. Let’s kill him and get the estate for ourselves!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they dragged him out of the vineyard and murdered him.
“What do you suppose the owner of the vineyard will do to them?” Jesus asked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ll tell you—he will come and kill those farmers and lease the vineyard to others.”
“How terrible that such a thing should ever happen,” his listeners protested.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus looked at them and said, “Then what does this Scripture mean?
‘The stone that the builders rejected
    has now become the cornerstone.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who stumbles over that stone will be broken to pieces, and it will crush anyone it falls on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The teachers of religious law and the leading priests wanted to arrest Jesus immediately because they realized he was telling the story against them—they were the wicked farmers. But they were afraid of the people’s reaction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Watching for their opportunity, the leaders sent spies pretending to be honest men. They tried to get Jesus to say something that could be reported to the Roman governor so he would arrest Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Teacher,” they said, “we know that you speak and teach what is right and are not influenced by what others think. You teach the way of God truthfully.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now tell us—is it right for us to pay taxes to Caesar or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He saw through their trickery and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Show me a Roman coin. Whose picture and title are stamped on it?”
“Caesar’s,” they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Well then,” he said, “give to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and give to God what belongs to God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they failed to trap him by what he said in front of the people. Instead, they were amazed by his answer, and they became silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus was approached by some Sadducees—religious leaders who say there is no resurrection from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: They posed this question: “Teacher, Moses gave us a law that if a man dies, leaving a wife but no children, his brother should marry the widow and have a child who will carry on the brother’s name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Well, suppose there were seven brothers. The oldest one married and then died without children.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the second brother married the widow, but he also died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the third brother married her. This continued with all seven of them, who died without children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the woman also died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So tell us, whose wife will she be in the resurrection? For all seven were married to her!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “Marriage is for people here on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the age to come, those worthy of being raised from the dead will neither marry nor be given in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they will never die again. In this respect they will be like angels. They are children of God and children of the resurrection.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But now, as to whether the dead will be raised—even Moses proved this when he wrote about the burning bush. Long after Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob had died, he referred to the Lord as ‘the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he is the God of the living, not the dead, for they are all alive to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Well said, Teacher!” remarked some of the teachers of religious law who were standing there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And then no one dared to ask him any more questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus presented them with a question. “Why is it,” he asked, “that the Messiah is said to be the son of David?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For David himself wrote in the book of Psalms:
‘The Lord said to my Lord,
    Sit in the place of honor at my right hand
speaker: Narrator

text:
until I humble your enemies,
    making them a footstool under your feet.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Since David called the Messiah ‘Lord,’ how can the Messiah be his son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, with the crowds listening, he turned to his disciples and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Beware of these teachers of religious law! For they like to parade around in flowing robes and love to receive respectful greetings as they walk in the marketplaces. And how they love the seats of honor in the synagogues and the head table at banquets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they shamelessly cheat widows out of their property and then pretend to be pious by making long prayers in public. Because of this, they will be severely punished.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jesus was in the Temple, he watched the rich people dropping their gifts in the collection box.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a poor widow came by and dropped in two small coins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell you the truth,” Jesus said, “this poor widow has given more than all the rest of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they have given a tiny part of their surplus, but she, poor as she is, has given everything she has.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of his disciples began talking about the majestic stonework of the Temple and the memorial decorations on the walls. But Jesus said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The time is coming when all these things will be completely demolished. Not one stone will be left on top of another!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Teacher,” they asked, “when will all this happen? What sign will show us that these things are about to take place?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Don’t let anyone mislead you, for many will come in my name, claiming, ‘I am the Messiah,’ and saying, ‘The time has come!’ But don’t believe them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when you hear of wars and insurrections, don’t panic. Yes, these things must take place first, but the end won’t follow immediately.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he added, “Nation will go to war against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be great earthquakes, and there will be famines and plagues in many lands, and there will be terrifying things and great miraculous signs from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But before all this occurs, there will be a time of great persecution. You will be dragged into synagogues and prisons, and you will stand trial before kings and governors because you are my followers.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this will be your opportunity to tell them about me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So don’t worry in advance about how to answer the charges against you,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I will give you the right words and such wisdom that none of your opponents will be able to reply or refute you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Even those closest to you—your parents, brothers, relatives, and friends—will betray you. They will even kill some of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And everyone will hate you because you are my followers.
speaker: Narrator

text: But not a hair of your head will perish!
speaker: Narrator

text: By standing firm, you will win your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then you will know that the time of its destruction has arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those in Judea must flee to the hills. Those in Jerusalem must get out, and those out in the country should not return to the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those will be days of God’s vengeance, and the prophetic words of the Scriptures will be fulfilled.
speaker: Narrator

text: How terrible it will be for pregnant women and for nursing mothers in those days. For there will be disaster in the land and great anger against this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be killed by the sword or sent away as captives to all the nations of the world. And Jerusalem will be trampled down by the Gentiles until the period of the Gentiles comes to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And there will be strange signs in the sun, moon, and stars. And here on earth the nations will be in turmoil, perplexed by the roaring seas and strange tides.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will be terrified at what they see coming upon the earth, for the powers in the heavens will be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then everyone will see the Son of Man coming on a cloud with power and great glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when all these things begin to happen, stand and look up, for your salvation is near!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he gave them this illustration: “Notice the fig tree, or any other tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the leaves come out, you know without being told that summer is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, when you see all these things taking place, you can know that the Kingdom of God is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you the truth, this generation will not pass from the scene until all these things have taken place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heaven and earth will disappear, but my words will never disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Watch out! Don’t let your hearts be dulled by carousing and drunkenness, and by the worries of this life. Don’t let that day catch you unaware,
speaker: Narrator

text: like a trap. For that day will come upon everyone living on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep alert at all times. And pray that you might be strong enough to escape these coming horrors and stand before the Son of Man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day Jesus went to the Temple to teach, and each evening he returned to spend the night on the Mount of Olives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowds gathered at the Temple early each morning to hear him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Festival of Unleavened Bread, which is also called Passover, was approaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leading priests and teachers of religious law were plotting how to kill Jesus, but they were afraid of the people’s reaction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Satan entered into Judas Iscariot, who was one of the twelve disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he went to the leading priests and captains of the Temple guard to discuss the best way to betray Jesus to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were delighted, and they promised to give him money.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he agreed and began looking for an opportunity to betray Jesus so they could arrest him when the crowds weren’t around.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Festival of Unleavened Bread arrived, when the Passover lamb is sacrificed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus sent Peter and John ahead and said, “Go and prepare the Passover meal, so we can eat it together.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Where do you want us to prepare it?” they asked him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “As soon as you enter Jerusalem, a man carrying a pitcher of water will meet you. Follow him. At the house he enters,
speaker: Narrator

text: say to the owner, ‘The Teacher asks: Where is the guest room where I can eat the Passover meal with my disciples?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take you upstairs to a large room that is already set up. That is where you should prepare our meal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They went off to the city and found everything just as Jesus had said, and they prepared the Passover meal there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came, Jesus and the apostles sat down together at the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, “I have been very eager to eat this Passover meal with you before my suffering begins.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I tell you now that I won’t eat this meal again until its meaning is fulfilled in the Kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took a cup of wine and gave thanks to God for it. Then he said, “Take this and share it among yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will not drink wine again until the Kingdom of God has come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He took some bread and gave thanks to God for it. Then he broke it in pieces and gave it to the disciples, saying, “This is my body, which is given for you. Do this in remembrance of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After supper he took another cup of wine and said, “This cup is the new covenant between God and his people—an agreement confirmed with my blood, which is poured out as a sacrifice for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But here at this table, sitting among us as a friend, is the man who will betray me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it has been determined that the Son of Man must die. But what sorrow awaits the one who betrays him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The disciples began to ask each other which of them would ever do such a thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they began to argue among themselves about who would be the greatest among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told them, “In this world the kings and great men lord it over their people, yet they are called ‘friends of the people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But among you it will be different. Those who are the greatest among you should take the lowest rank, and the leader should be like a servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is more important, the one who sits at the table or the one who serves? The one who sits at the table, of course. But not here! For I am among you as one who serves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have stayed with me in my time of trial.
speaker: Narrator

text: And just as my Father has granted me a Kingdom, I now grant you the right
speaker: Narrator

text: to eat and drink at my table in my Kingdom. And you will sit on thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Simon, Simon, Satan has asked to sift each of you like wheat.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have pleaded in prayer for you, Simon, that your faith should not fail. So when you have repented and turned to me again, strengthen your brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter said, “Lord, I am ready to go to prison with you, and even to die with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus said, “Peter, let me tell you something. Before the rooster crows tomorrow morning, you will deny three times that you even know me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jesus asked them, “When I sent you out to preach the Good News and you did not have money, a traveler’s bag, or an extra pair of sandals, did you need anything?”
“No,” they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But now,” he said, “take your money and a traveler’s bag. And if you don’t have a sword, sell your cloak and buy one!
speaker: Narrator

text: For the time has come for this prophecy about me to be fulfilled: ‘He was counted among the rebels.’ Yes, everything written about me by the prophets will come true.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, Lord,” they replied, “we have two swords among us.”
“That’s enough,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, accompanied by the disciples, Jesus left the upstairs room and went as usual to the Mount of Olives.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he told them, “Pray that you will not give in to temptation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked away, about a stone’s throw, and knelt down and prayed,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Father, if you are willing, please take this cup of suffering away from me. Yet I want your will to be done, not mine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then an angel from heaven appeared and strengthened him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He prayed more fervently, and he was in such agony of spirit that his sweat fell to the ground like great drops of blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: At last he stood up again and returned to the disciples, only to find them asleep, exhausted from grief.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why are you sleeping?” he asked them. “Get up and pray, so that you will not give in to temptation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But even as Jesus said this, a crowd approached, led by Judas, one of the twelve disciples. Judas walked over to Jesus to greet him with a kiss.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus said, “Judas, would you betray the Son of Man with a kiss?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the other disciples saw what was about to happen, they exclaimed, “Lord, should we fight? We brought the swords!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And one of them struck at the high priest’s slave, slashing off his right ear.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus said, “No more of this.” And he touched the man’s ear and healed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus spoke to the leading priests, the captains of the Temple guard, and the elders who had come for him. “Am I some dangerous revolutionary,” he asked, “that you come with swords and clubs to arrest me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why didn’t you arrest me in the Temple? I was there every day. But this is your moment, the time when the power of darkness reigns.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they arrested him and led him to the high priest’s home. And Peter followed at a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: The guards lit a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat around it, and Peter joined them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: A servant girl noticed him in the firelight and began staring at him. Finally she said, “This man was one of Jesus’ followers!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter denied it. “Woman,” he said, “I don’t even know him!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
After a while someone else looked at him and said, “You must be one of them!”
“No, man, I’m not!” Peter retorted.
speaker: Narrator

text: About an hour later someone else insisted, “This must be one of them, because he is a Galilean, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter said, “Man, I don’t know what you are talking about.” And immediately, while he was still speaking, the rooster crowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that moment the Lord turned and looked at Peter. Suddenly, the Lord’s words flashed through Peter’s mind: “Before the rooster crows tomorrow morning, you will deny three times that you even know me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Peter left the courtyard, weeping bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The guards in charge of Jesus began mocking and beating him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They blindfolded him and said, “Prophesy to us! Who hit you that time?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they hurled all sorts of terrible insults at him.
speaker: Narrator

text: At daybreak all the elders of the people assembled, including the leading priests and the teachers of religious law. Jesus was led before this high council,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and they said, “Tell us, are you the Messiah?”
But he replied, “If I tell you, you won’t believe me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if I ask you a question, you won’t answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from now on the Son of Man will be seated in the place of power at God’s right hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They all shouted, “So, are you claiming to be the Son of God?”
And he replied, “You say that I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why do we need other witnesses?” they said. “We ourselves heard him say it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the entire council took Jesus to Pilate, the Roman governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: They began to state their case: “This man has been leading our people astray by telling them not to pay their taxes to the Roman government and by claiming he is the Messiah, a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Pilate asked him, “Are you the king of the Jews?”
Jesus replied, “You have said it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pilate turned to the leading priests and to the crowd and said, “I find nothing wrong with this man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they became insistent. “But he is causing riots by his teaching wherever he goes—all over Judea, from Galilee to Jerusalem!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Oh, is he a Galilean?” Pilate asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they said that he was, Pilate sent him to Herod Antipas, because Galilee was under Herod’s jurisdiction, and Herod happened to be in Jerusalem at the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Herod was delighted at the opportunity to see Jesus, because he had heard about him and had been hoping for a long time to see him perform a miracle.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked Jesus question after question, but Jesus refused to answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the leading priests and the teachers of religious law stood there shouting their accusations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Herod and his soldiers began mocking and ridiculing Jesus. Finally, they put a royal robe on him and sent him back to Pilate.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Herod and Pilate, who had been enemies before, became friends that day.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pilate called together the leading priests and other religious leaders, along with the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he announced his verdict. “You brought this man to me, accusing him of leading a revolt. I have examined him thoroughly on this point in your presence and find him innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Herod came to the same conclusion and sent him back to us. Nothing this man has done calls for the death penalty.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will have him flogged, and then I will release him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a mighty roar rose from the crowd, and with one voice they shouted, “Kill him, and release Barabbas to us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Barabbas was in prison for taking part in an insurrection in Jerusalem against the government, and for murder.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Pilate argued with them, because he wanted to release Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they kept shouting, “Crucify him! Crucify him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the third time he demanded, “Why? What crime has he committed? I have found no reason to sentence him to death. So I will have him flogged, and then I will release him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the mob shouted louder and louder, demanding that Jesus be crucified, and their voices prevailed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pilate sentenced Jesus to die as they demanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they had requested, he released Barabbas, the man in prison for insurrection and murder. But he turned Jesus over to them to do as they wished.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they led Jesus away, a man named Simon, who was from Cyrene, happened to be coming in from the countryside. The soldiers seized him and put the cross on him and made him carry it behind Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: A large crowd trailed behind, including many grief-stricken women.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus turned and said to them, “Daughters of Jerusalem, don’t weep for me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the days are coming when they will say, ‘Fortunate indeed are the women who are childless, the wombs that have not borne a child and the breasts that have never nursed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: People will beg the mountains, ‘Fall on us,’ and plead with the hills, ‘Bury us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For if these things are done when the tree is green, what will happen when it is dry?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Two others, both criminals, were led out to be executed with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to a place called The Skull, they nailed him to the cross. And the criminals were also crucified—one on his right and one on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, “Father, forgive them, for they don’t know what they are doing.” And the soldiers gambled for his clothes by throwing dice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd watched and the leaders scoffed. “He saved others,” they said, “let him save himself if he is really God’s Messiah, the Chosen One.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers mocked him, too, by offering him a drink of sour wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They called out to him, “If you are the King of the Jews, save yourself!”
speaker: Narrator

text: A sign was fastened above him with these words: “This is the King of the Jews.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the criminals hanging beside him scoffed, “So you’re the Messiah, are you? Prove it by saving yourself—and us, too, while you’re at it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the other criminal protested, “Don’t you fear God even when you have been sentenced to die?
speaker: Narrator

text: We deserve to die for our crimes, but this man hasn’t done anything wrong.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Jesus, remember me when you come into your Kingdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jesus replied, “I assure you, today you will be with me in paradise.”
speaker: Narrator

text: By this time it was about noon, and darkness fell across the whole land until three o’clock.
speaker: Narrator

text: The light from the sun was gone. And suddenly, the curtain in the sanctuary of the Temple was torn down the middle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus shouted, “Father, I entrust my spirit into your hands!” And with those words he breathed his last.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Roman officer overseeing the execution saw what had happened, he worshiped God and said, “Surely this man was innocent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when all the crowd that came to see the crucifixion saw what had happened, they went home in deep sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus’ friends, including the women who had followed him from Galilee, stood at a distance watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a good and righteous man named Joseph. He was a member of the Jewish high council,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he had not agreed with the decision and actions of the other religious leaders. He was from the town of Arimathea in Judea, and he was waiting for the Kingdom of God to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to Pilate and asked for Jesus’ body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took the body down from the cross and wrapped it in a long sheet of linen cloth and laid it in a new tomb that had been carved out of rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was done late on Friday afternoon, the day of preparation, as the Sabbath was about to begin.
speaker: Narrator

text: As his body was taken away, the women from Galilee followed and saw the tomb where his body was placed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went home and prepared spices and ointments to anoint his body. But by the time they were finished the Sabbath had begun, so they rested as required by the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: But very early on Sunday morning the women went to the tomb, taking the spices they had prepared.
speaker: Narrator

text: They found that the stone had been rolled away from the entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went in, but they didn’t find the body of the Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they stood there puzzled, two men suddenly appeared to them, clothed in dazzling robes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The women were terrified and bowed with their faces to the ground. Then the men asked, “Why are you looking among the dead for someone who is alive?
speaker: Narrator

text: He isn’t here! He is risen from the dead! Remember what he told you back in Galilee,
speaker: Narrator

text: that the Son of Man must be betrayed into the hands of sinful men and be crucified, and that he would rise again on the third day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they remembered that he had said this.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they rushed back from the tomb to tell his eleven disciples—and everyone else—what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and several other women who told the apostles what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the story sounded like nonsense to the men, so they didn’t believe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Peter jumped up and ran to the tomb to look. Stooping, he peered in and saw the empty linen wrappings; then he went home again, wondering what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day two of Jesus’ followers were walking to the village of Emmaus, seven miles from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they walked along they were talking about everything that had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they talked and discussed these things, Jesus himself suddenly came and began walking with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God kept them from recognizing him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked them, “What are you discussing so intently as you walk along?”
They stopped short, sadness written across their faces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of them, Cleopas, replied, “You must be the only person in Jerusalem who hasn’t heard about all the things that have happened there the last few days.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What things?” Jesus asked.
“The things that happened to Jesus, the man from Nazareth,” they said. “He was a prophet who did powerful miracles, and he was a mighty teacher in the eyes of God and all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But our leading priests and other religious leaders handed him over to be condemned to death, and they crucified him.
speaker: Narrator

text: We had hoped he was the Messiah who had come to rescue Israel. This all happened three days ago.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then some women from our group of his followers were at his tomb early this morning, and they came back with an amazing report.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said his body was missing, and they had seen angels who told them Jesus is alive!
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of our men ran out to see, and sure enough, his body was gone, just as the women had said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to them, “You foolish people! You find it so hard to believe all that the prophets wrote in the Scriptures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wasn’t it clearly predicted that the Messiah would have to suffer all these things before entering his glory?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus took them through the writings of Moses and all the prophets, explaining from all the Scriptures the things concerning himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: By this time they were nearing Emmaus and the end of their journey. Jesus acted as if he were going on,
speaker: Narrator

text: but they begged him, “Stay the night with us, since it is getting late.” So he went home with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they sat down to eat, he took the bread and blessed it. Then he broke it and gave it to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. And at that moment he disappeared!
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to each other, “Didn’t our hearts burn within us as he talked with us on the road and explained the Scriptures to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And within the hour they were on their way back to Jerusalem. There they found the eleven disciples and the others who had gathered with them,
speaker: Narrator

text: who said, “The Lord has really risen! He appeared to Peter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two from Emmaus told their story of how Jesus had appeared to them as they were walking along the road, and how they had recognized him as he was breaking the bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: And just as they were telling about it, Jesus himself was suddenly standing there among them. “Peace be with you,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the whole group was startled and frightened, thinking they were seeing a ghost!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why are you frightened?” he asked. “Why are your hearts filled with doubt?
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at my hands. Look at my feet. You can see that it’s really me. Touch me and make sure that I am not a ghost, because ghosts don’t have bodies, as you see that I do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he spoke, he showed them his hands and his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still they stood there in disbelief, filled with joy and wonder. Then he asked them, “Do you have anything here to eat?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave him a piece of broiled fish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he ate it as they watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “When I was with you before, I told you that everything written about me in the law of Moses and the prophets and in the Psalms must be fulfilled.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he opened their minds to understand the Scriptures.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Yes, it was written long ago that the Messiah would suffer and die and rise from the dead on the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was also written that this message would be proclaimed in the authority of his name to all the nations, beginning in Jerusalem: ‘There is forgiveness of sins for all who repent.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You are witnesses of all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now I will send the Holy Spirit, just as my Father promised. But stay here in the city until the Holy Spirit comes and fills you with power from heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus led them to Bethany, and lifting his hands to heaven, he blessed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was blessing them, he left them and was taken up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they worshiped him and then returned to Jerusalem filled with great joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they spent all of their time in the Temple, praising God.
speaker: Narrator
